HEADLINE: A Road Map of Her Own 

BYLINE:  By DYAN ZASLOWSKY; DYAN ZASLOWSKY lives in Denver.

 BODY:
MY visit to Tel Aviv in late May began with a bang at a sophisticated cafe when I swung off my backpack and knocked over a chair. The chair hit the stone floor with such a sharp crack it stopped conversation at nearby tables, and I do not think I imagined that there was an instant when patrons looked poised to run for cover or the door. In that same moment they must also have discerned that I was klutzy but not dangerous, and animatedly picked up the pieces of their sentences. I was so embarrassed I wanted to slink out of the country, which would have been a shame since there are not many of my kind in Israel these days. 
 Israelis, not tourists, peopled the cafe that night. All the disturbances more deadly than the one I made have eviscerated the country's travel economy, slashing it by 60 percent in the last three years. On account of the Palestinian uprising -- or the situation, as Israelis euphemistically call it -- big hotels loom like abandoned citadels against the night. In the artists' maze of Jaffa many chic galleries are sealed behind harlequin-patterned iron gates. The Arab souk in the Old City of Jerusalem that teemed with sightseers and shoppers when I last visited 31 years ago is almost deserted now, and near it, the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, resplendent in tiny mosaic and gold leaf, greets few. 
Anxiety about suicide bombers in Israel is so strong that even free youth tours from the United States are hard pressed to fill spaces. But fear, I quickly discovered, was far more palpable outside Israel than in it. "They must pump some anesthetizing agent into the planes when they land at Ben-Gurion Airport," joked one friend who has remained a staunch Israel traveler. 
 For part of my two-week vacation I traveled with a group of five that included my sister Nina and my daughter Hilary. Our primary security measure was to hire a guide who drove us around the country in a bulletproof van and escorted us almost everywhere. 
 Our driving trip coincided with President Bush's hopeful pronouncements in Aqaba, Jordan, and we felt as safe in Israel as we do in the United States -- except when we encountered reckless Israeli drivers, who hurt more people than Palestinian suicide bombers do. We saw Israelis going to cafes, throngs of them dancing on the beach, riding buses, attending soccer matches and publicly celebrating holidays. Young soldiers toting M-16's, and guards who search bags at the entrance to malls and hotels create an atmosphere of calm alertness, not heightened anxiety. The Israelis we met seem to shrug off fear.
 Hilary had just completed a college semester in Paris where she sampled nihilism served up with espresso at doily-size tables, and was moved to generalize about the difference between the French national mood she had experienced and the Israeli one. In France nothing matters because we will all die anyway, she said. In Israel everything matters for the same reason. 
 Since everything matters the smallest gestures must also count, though they are seldom reported by news media programmed to lead with disaster. Throughout the trip I felt that the silent accumulation of small kindnesses led to something quite extraordinary. We experienced so many situations suggesting that both sides just wanted to get along that we actually thought peace might break out any minute. 
 Consider a few examples. Our guide, Moshe, is planning an interdenominational tour from Israel to Iraq this fall; large signs on the Tel Aviv beach proclaim "Go in Peace" inEnglish, Arabic and Hebrew. Where the Sea of Galilee laps tranquilly at the rock shore beneath the Church of the Primacy of St. Peter, a large group of South Koreans -- who even now fill Israel's tour buses -- sang sweet hymns. And outside the Jaffa Gate in Jerusalem an Arab woman was nursing her baby in a retreating patch of shade. She had one palm outstretched, and while I fished money out of my pack an Orthodox Jew in a long black coat and black hat came along. He reached into his pocket and pulled out a few shekels, placing them gently in the woman's hand and then quickly walked on. 
 That night the Jewish holiday of Shavuot, commemorating the giving of the Torah, would begin. As is customary I planned to stay up late and study Jewish text, but I had trouble finding the address of the yeshiva I wanted to go to. Two Arab employees at my hotel offered to help by looking in the Jerusalem phone book with me. Yussef thumbed through the pages under the Hebrew letter yud, and marveled at how many yeshivas there were in the city. 
 Even business has had its modest successes. After the Palestinian uprising began in September 2000, Baruch Hadaya thought he might have to close his tiny jewelry shop in the Jewish Quarter of the Old City because there were no customers for his costly custom gold and diamond pieces. But now Mr. Hadaya, a secular Jew, is better off than he was before, thanks to a craving for his wares among hundreds of Orthodox yeshiva girls. 
 When his high-end trade disappeared Mr. Hadaya began inscribing inexpensive silver rings with a single saying in Hebrew that, depending on the situation, can instantly make a person happy or sad: "This too shall pass," it reads, rescuing Mr. Hadaya and his shop, at least for the time being. The yeshiva girls still stream in to buy these rings and listen to Mr. Hadaya's stories, returning to purchase more rings and bracelets with Hebrew quotes of their own choosing. "This too shall pass" sums up the ache of joy and sorrow travelers encounter in Israel whenever they go, and the fleeting obligation to partake of both. 
 Peace is not only the absence of war but also the balancing of conflicting interests, according to some Jewish scholars. On Shavuot, which this year coincided with the Muslim Sabbath, we saw what that balance already looks like. Hilary and I and two friends woke before dawn to walk to the Kotel, or Western Wall, joining tens of thousands of Jews who moved fearlessly through the dim and shuttered Arab souk to enter the sprawling square in front of the wall.
 From the back of the women's section I watched a sea of swaying men in black davening and singing as the sun climbed the Temple Mount, softly illuminating the Kotel and the gold and silver orbs of the Dome of the Rock and Al Aksa Mosque. 
 Most Jews left the Old City well before noon to go home and sleep. After we napped we went back to explore further, stopping at a cafe owned by a Palestinian for tall glasses of freshly squeezed orange juice. Our guide drove out of the Old City and then headed east. We crept along the narrow road that runs through the Kidron Valley because of the heavy incoming pedestrian and car traffic. Before us was a gathering sea of Muslims bound for Al Aksa. It was their turn to pray.

HEADLINE: North by Northeast, An Inn by the River 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT; DAVID LEONHARDT reports on economics for The Times.

 BODY:
WE knew what we wanted when we were planning our vacation last summer, but we were not sure where to find it on this side of the ocean.
 The previous year, my wife, Laura, and I rented a cottage on the outskirts of a golden hilltop village in southern France. We drove through mountainous countryside to shop at markets in the morning, played cards in the afternoon sun and cooked salmon on one of the world's worst electric grills at night. It was the best vacation I ever had. 
 This time, a welcome pregnancy and the unwelcome August air fares to Europe were conspiring to keep us closer to home. But we now knew what we were looking for: a landscape that was ample entertainment for much of the day and local food that filled in the rest. 
 We found our solution at an inn on the northern banks of the St. Lawrence River, 300 miles from where it last touches the United States. Starting in Montreal, we drove northeast, past Quebec City and on to the comparative quiet of Route 138, a plunging road that forms the spine of a region known as Charlevoix.
 During some ascents, only 10 yards of road were visible in front of the cars; on the way down, we sometimes seemed to be headed straight into the river. For a passenger, staring at the countryside, patched with wheat and red-trimmed white houses, became both a necessity and a delight.
 Charlevoix has long been a summer retreat for French Canadians and for the occasional American, including President William Howard Taft. Between the farms and small hotels, it is a center for art galleries and home to some of the best whale watching in the eastern part of North America. We bypassed Mr. Taft's favorite spot, the 405-room Manoir Richelieu, which still has the golf course he ceremonially opened in 1925 and has since added a casino. Our more modest destination was La Pinsonniere, a small resort hovering above the river, with a restaurant, a spa and a nearly perfect porch. 
 In the sunlight of late summer, that porch gives La Pinsonniere a grandeur of its own. Ten miles wide here, the St. Lawrence is more than double the broadest part of the Mississippi, and its varied blues stretch for miles. The porch is the place where guests tend to gather for the day's last light.
 What goes on the tables, however, is as important to the inn's appeal -- and to Charlevoix's -- as the view from them. Just behind is a footbridge crossing a tiny herb garden, from which a chef gathered thyme and dill one afternoon for that night's dinner. Through a set of doors leading to the lobby, is a small, well-stocked bar that serves evening snacks like crudites and refreshingly light fried cheese. 
 Outside the inn, back out on Route 138, is Charlevoix's Route des Saveurs, a trail of farms and shops that sell the region's produce, cheese and game. They welcome visitors and play an important role on the short, rotating menu at the inn's deservedly well-known restaurant. 
 Opened 25 years ago in a house built in the 1950's, La Pinsonniere lacks the weathered charm that many travelers want from an inn. Fortunately, though, the owners do not aspire to a history they cannot claim, and we found the wood-paneled common areas, with sofas, leather chairs, a fireplace, and backgammon and chess sets, to be cozy enough. Friendly staff members are always in the vicinity, happy to offer a drink or advice about local activities, and careful not to pester.
 When we told a woman at the front desk one evening that we wanted to go out for dinner and were looking for a simple restaurant in the best meaning of the term, she steered us toward Auberge Petite Madeleine in nearby St.-Simeon. There, we sat among Currier and Ives prints and old kitchen cans bearing Ritz and other brand names, in a room that felt as though it was part of somebody's house. At reasonable prices, we enjoyed Quebecois comfort food like a simple baked fish plate and upside-down blueberry cake.
 Turning over every decision to La Pinsonniere's staff would be a mistake, however. Like the common areas, all of the 25 guest rooms are well kept and comfortable, but the rooms without a river view are wholly unremarkable, while those with the view are splendid. Do not be tempted by the whirlpool bathtub, sauna or deck that accompany some of the rooms with the euphemistic "village view." 
 One floor beneath the lobby, a 20-by-40-foot indoor pool allowed me to pretend that I was making up for the previous night's fried cheese. There is a tennis court, too, near the beginning of a downhill path leading to the river's rocky shore. 
 Laura and I spent much of our days driving along Route 138, gawking at the changing views on the twisting road and stopping to shop. A store called Les Jardins du Centre, little more than a farm stand, was my favorite. One step through the door, and the room smelled richly of the raspberries being cooked into jam in the back. We bought a few tomatoes that were the equal of New Jersey's and some blue potatoes that the locals in front of us in line suggested cutting in half and roasting in oil. Back in New York, my mother, who received our uncooked leftovers, pronounced them the best potatoes she had ever tasted.
 Elsewhere in Charlevoix's riverside towns like Baie-St.-Paul, St.-Joseph-de-la-Rive and Les Eboulements, we stopped at a paper-making store that gave demonstrations and a lamb farm selling oversized sunflowers for one Canadian dollar apiece. 
 Thanks to van Gogh, sunflowers tend to bring France to my mind. But the analogy does not seem quite right in Charlevoix. The undulating farmland resembles the landscape of northern New England, not Provence, and many of the galleries and studios lining the roads have a cheerful newness to them. Wine is an afterthought here. Route 138's flavor trail includes a cider mill but no vineyards. 
 THERE is something reassuring about the differences. Charlevoix is its own place, not a theme park version of the Old World. Unlike the most visited parts of nearby Quebec City, where T-shirt sellers are easier to find than grocers, Charlevoix's stores exist to serve both tourists and residents.
 Our one disappointment, in fact, came at the casual restaurant at Mr. Taft's Manoir Richelieu. Laura decided it was worthy of the ultimate insult for pub food: if we ate there again, we would order vegetarian. 
 One memorable dinner at La Pinsonniere more than made up for that experience. From the spoonful of duck and lamb curry that came as a chef's appetizer to the maple souffle, each course exceeded the standard set by the previous one. Roasted quail and smoked Atlantic salmon followed the curry. The centerpiece of venison and black currants in a brandy and veal-stock sauce was as rich in flavor as it was in color. 
 By the meal's end, the moon, looking massive in the low sky, illuminated the river below the restaurant's windows, and we knew we had succeeded in satisfying both our stomachs and our eyes. 

The comforts of Quebec
The drive to Charlevoix from Quebec takes three to four hours.

Lodging and Dining
La Pinsonniere, 124, St. -Raphael, La Malbaie (secteur Cap-a-l'Aigle), Quebec, Canada G5A 1X9; (800) 387-4431, fax (418) 665-7156; www.lapinsonniere.com. May through October, rooms are $107 to $465 for a two-bedroom suite, based on $1.40 Canadian to the U.S. dollar. Standard rooms are $164. Not all of these rooms have a river view, though, so be sure to ask when making a reservation. For $340, you can stay in the premium deluxe room, which includes a king bed, a fireplace, a balcony and a sauna. There is a two-night minimum stay during weekends. Most rooms cost about $18 less a night during the low season.
 Fixed-priced menus at the restaurant are $43 (three courses), $61 (five) and $82 (seven) a person, not including wine. You can also order a la carte. Entrees are $29 to $34. 
 The inn's spa offers massages and other treatments individually, or you can buy a few as part of a package. A 50-minute massage costs $50. 
 At Auberge Petite Madeleine de Port-au-Persil, 400, route Port-au-Persil, St.-Simeon; (418) 638-2460, our dinner was $50 with tip and a half-bottle of wine.

Sightseeing
 At La Pinsonniere, you can pick up a helpful guide to Charlevoix's Route de Saveur, which lists nearby food shops and restaurants. A few of our favorites were in the nearby town of Les Eboulements. Les Jardins du Centre, (418)-635-2387, sells mainly produce. Ferme Eboulmontaise, (418) 635-2682, allows visitors to walk around its small sheep barn and vegetable gardens. A restaurant on the property is open every day except Tuesday.
 Croisieres 2001, (418) 235-3333, www.croisieres2001.com, and Croisieres AML, (800) 563-4643, www.croisieresaml.com, both run whale-watching cruises in the nearby Saguenay Fjord. The boat rides last about three hours and cost $35, and $14 for children between the ages of 6 and 16.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
SARS Abates in Toronto, But Tourism Still Lags

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: TORONTO 

 BODY:
SUMMER is the time when Americans are attracted by Toronto's lakeside beaches, a slew of music festivals, a high-scoring baseball team and many sites, like Niagara Falls, within easy driving distance. But this summer is emerging as a major disappointment for Toronto's hotels and restaurants, which depend on a seasonal wave of American tourists. 
 The city's woes begin with a Canadian dollar that has rapidly appreciated most of the year, considerably flattening the wallets of Americans who make up the lion's share of foreign visitors. Air Canada, the main carrier between the United States and Toronto and other Canadian destinations, is tottering in bankruptcy protection -- lowering confidence among some travel agents about buying the airline's tickets well in advance. A limited outbreak of mad cow disease in Alberta in May raised concerns about the food supply. 
And most important, the outbreak of SARS in March made Toronto a city that travelers have been avoiding. On July 2, the city was finally taken off the World Health Organization list of SARS-impacted areas, and on July 9 the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention lifted its travel alert on Canada. Still, spokesmen for several Toronto hotels said there had been only a slight increase in reservations. "We'll see some short-term impact," said Cynthia Bond of the Starwood Hotels and Resorts, which runs five hotels in Toronto. But it is still going to be some time before things pick up, she added. 
 For those Americans who do visit Toronto, there are some attractive opportunities. The best tables at the restaurant atop CN Tower and many other fashionable dining spots can be had with little or no wait. Good tickets for acclaimed theater productions at the Shaw Festival in nearby Niagara-on-the-Lake can be bought at the last minute on most nights. And there are bargain packages galore, including some with tickets to a Rolling Stones concert Wednesday organized by local officials and by Molson Sports and Entertainment designed to celebrate the end of the SARS outbreak and tell the world Toronto is alive and well. (See www.iam.ca/rollingstones.)
 The Canadian tourism industry has started an aggressive advertising campaign that has included a humorous print advertisement with an enticing glimpse of Quebec City that offered Canada as a Plan B for those who thought better of this Plan A: "Given the economy and worldwide uncertainty, maybe this is the summer to stay in the U.S. and visit those distant relatives."
Plan B includes some bargains.
 Hertz, for instance, is offering free admission to CN Tower, the Toronto Zoo and a free helicopter tour of Niagara Falls among other perks for some weekly or weekend rentals of a full-size car in Toronto through Aug. 31. 
 SARS was never much of a threat to travelers visiting Toronto, according to local health officials. It remained mostly isolated in hospitals, where it spread for four months, and few if any cases were spread in the street.
 The perception that travel to Toronto was unsafe was based on relentless news media coverage as the death count rose to about 40, making the city the most affected outside Asia. The World Health Organization issued a travel advisory in late April warning travelers to postpone unnecessary travel to the city. The advisory was in place only six days, but it ravaged the travel industry. In May the city was taken off the SARS-affected list, but for less than two weeks, when a second cluster of SARS patients was identified and the listing was reinstated in early July.
 Cancellations of travel bookings, particularly of conventions, will have an impact on the local economy until well into 2004, according to recent studies.
 Hotel occupancy in Toronto was down 21 percent in April, the month SARS was at its peak, from the same month in 2002. About half of Toronto's 95,000 tourism workers had their work hours cut or were laid off entirely as hotels and restaurants struggled to cut costs.
 The damage stretched across the country, as the Canadian tourism industry's losses in 2003 are being projected at nearly $400 million (American), according to the Canadian Tourism Commission. Western Alberta, the SARS-free home of Lake Louise, Banff and Jasper, has reported a decrease in foreign tourism spending of up to 15 percent from last year. Montreal, also SARS-free, but much closer to Toronto and at least as cosmopolitan, reported estimated tourism losses of almost $40 million as many hotels reported that bookings were down 10 percent in recent months.
 "Perception versus reality was just so skewed," said Rod Seiling, president of the Greater Toronto Hotel Association. "In terms of having a regular summer, we're past that point."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Asbury Park; 
After Bleak Years, Signs of Progress

BYLINE:  By JERRY CHESLOW

 BODY:
IT has taken more than 30 years, but Asbury Park, N.J., crushed by race riots that drove out its middle class and sent it into a tailspin of poverty and municipal corruption, is seeing recovery, sometimes dramatic, in some of its neighborhoods. Fueled by an influx of gays, empty nesters and rock fans, property prices are booming in parts of the city, and stores are opening.
 But the recovery is still fragile. There is little foot traffic on Cookman Avenue, the main business street, and more than half the stores are vacant, with their windows boarded up, soaped up or cracked. Looming northward in the distance, at the oceanfront, is the rusting skeleton of an unfinished 11-story luxury high-rise -- a relic of a failed redevelopment effort started in the late 1980's. 
 According to the 2000 census, 30 percent of the population lives below the poverty line and only 20 percent of the residents own the homes in which they live. A former city administration is involved in a corruption scandal. A former city manager is awaiting sentencing for bribe taking, and a former mayor, a former councilman and a former head of the local housing authority are all under indictment on similar charges. 
Nevertheless, on many streets, Dumpsters occupy driveways and the whine of power saws fills the air. Whole blocks of Victorians along Sunset and Deal Lakes in the northeastern quadrant have been completely restored by urban pioneers. Many of those homes are at least 3,000 square feet and had been divided into rental apartments during Asbury Park's scruffier days. Now, they are being reconverted into luxury single-family houses. 
"Some homes that were difficult to sell for $100,000 four years ago are now going for $600,000," said Jim McGlynn, a sales associate at Genesis Realty and Management on Cookman Avenue. "Six of ten of my buyers are gay couples, who love Victorian, the shore and multicultural communities and don't have the same need for a good school system that heterosexuals do." Mr. McGlynn said others are empty nesters and Bruce Springsteen fans, attracted to Asbury after the rock star introduced his album "The Rising" on the beach for the "Today" show last July.
The lure of inexpensive shore housing drew William D. Whitefield and his partner, Christopher Vendi, both actors, to Asbury Park two years ago. "We heard that it was improving and that gay people, artists and families were starting to move in," Mr. Whitefield said. With the help of a redevelopment program sponsored by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development and a 3 percent down payment, they purchased a two-family Victorian that required minimal work for $214,000. 
"Just four months later, we were offered $385,000," Mr. Whitefield said. "I feel like we got the last great deal in Asbury Park."
The couple has since refurbished their home and rented out the bottom floor. Although they love watching the house-by-house reconstruction of Asbury Park, they are reminded each morning of how far it still has to go. "We spend mornings just picking up litter thrown out of car windows that lands outside our house," said Mr. Whitefield. 
According to Mr. McGlynn, the remodeling boom that started in the northeast is flowing southward and westward, toward the New Jersey Transit tracks on the fringe of the crowded southwestern quadrant, where most low-income residents live. Those houses, too, are being snapped up, but by investors, who are renting them out to people who were displaced when the larger Victorians were reconverted.
AT the end of July, 132 single-family homes were listed for sale on the Multiple Listing Service, ranging from $95,000 for a two-bedroom ranch on Avenue A in the southwestern section up to $695,000 for a six-bedroom 1920's center hall colonial on Eighth Avenue, facing Deal Lake. 
Also appreciating are apartments in the 14 condominium buildings. They range from $70,000 for a one-bedroom in Park Place, a converted hotel at the corner of Park Place and Sixth Avenue, up to $400,000 for a two-bedroom in the nine-story Santander, built on Deal Lake in the 1920's.
The largest condominium building is the 100-unit, 12-story Deal Lake Towers on Deal Lake Drive. According to Walter M. Clark, a sales associate at Park Place Realty on Main Street, one-bedroom units that he sold in the building for $26,000 each after a bank foreclosure four years ago recently sold for up to $165,000 apiece.
Along Cookman Avenue, many of the shuttered stores have been purchased by developers, who are building condominium apartments above them, in a move that city officials hope will reinvigorate the downtown. Recent sales of those condos range from $265,000 to $295,000.
Several new restaurants have opened in the past year on Cookman and neighboring Main Street, including Harry's Roadhouse, a restaurant and nightclub in a cavernous converted clothing store with exposed brick walls. It serves Southern fare and drinks from a bar flanked by a red 1920's Texaco Fire Chief gasoline pump. On weekend nights, when disk jockeys and bands are working, it employs as many as 10 bouncers and can draw 360 diners, according to the general manager, Andrew Thompson.
"By now, we were also hoping for a walk-in lunch trade," said Mr. Thompson, surveying his nearly vacant establishment on a Friday afternoon. "This is still a tough area, and I think it will takeat least two years until Cookman Avenue becomes a destination place so that we can start making a profit."
For potential residents with children, the problems of the 3,500-student Asbury Park School District are a concern. Its high school dropout rate is 11 percent, compared with a state average of 2.7 percent, and one-fourth of its students are in special education programs, some with problems related to their mothers' substance abuse during pregnancy. With an $80 million annual budget, the district has one of the highest per-pupil spending rates in New Jersey. Class sizes hover about 19 students, better than the state average of 20.4, and Asbury Park has one computer for every 1.6 students at the high school level, compared with one of four students statewide.
Nevertheless, the district is the lowest-scoring in Monmouth County on standardized tests. On last year's SAT reasoning test, Asbury Park students achieved combined verbal and mathematics scores of 778, compared with a state average of 1,009. 
The superintendent of schools, Antonio N. Lewis, who was appointed three years ago, says he is turning around a system that was in chaos when he inherited it, with just 16 percent of students reading at grade level. "Nobody was watching the store," Dr. Lewis said.
A four-member task force drafted a 41-page plan to overhaul hiring practices, develop new curriculum and update job descriptions, draft new educational policies and improve oversight and monitoring. 
Three years later, according to Kathy McDavid, a member of the task force and director of curriculum, test scores have improved significantly, with 64 percent of students in the largest of the three elementary schools, the 735-student Thurgood Marshall School, reading at grade level. Mrs. McDavid believes it will take up to seven years to complete the turnaround in the school system.
New Jersey's deputy commissioner of education, Dwight R. Pfennig, acknowledges that Dr. Lewis and his staff are making progress, especially at the elementary level. "Our major thrust in New Jersey is to have all students literate by third grade," Dr. Pfennig said. "We have great hope that this district will eventually do so, but we find unacceptable the projection of a turnaround in seven years. We must build the educational capacity of the district faster."
WITH its problems, Asbury Park might cause despair to its founder, a devout Methodist industrialist named James Adam Bradley, who named the city for Francis Asbury, an 18th-century circuit-riding preacher credited with establishing the denomination in the Americas. According to Werner Baumgartner, the city historian, Mr. Bradley set up one of the first boards of health in the United States shortly after the city's founding in 1871. His inspectors regularly visited homes to ensure that the garbage was bagged, the windows were screened and there was no livestock or alcohol in the homes. "Until the 1920's, Asbury Park was one of the only 'dry' beachfront resorts in the country," he said.
The famous Asbury boardwalk, nine-tenths of a mile long and built in 1930, is bookended by two huge brick and steel Beaux-Arts buildings -- the Casino, a building used for entertainment in a bygone era, to the south and Convention Hall to the north -- both of which are in need of restoration. By 1940, there were about 200 hotels; today, there is only one, the Berkeley Carteret, built in 1925.
In the 1950's and 1960's, Asbury Park was an entertainment destination, with clubs like the Stone Pony, where Bruce Springsteen got his start and still plays. By the mid-1960's, urban flight began; and on July 4, 1970, race riots gutted much of the city, sealing its fate as a backwater. 
Local officials say redevelopment is really coming to Asbury Park this time, after a new City Council, elected in July 2001, appointed a new city manager, settled lawsuits with the bankrupt developer of the 11-story skeleton and approved a new redevelopment plan on June 25, 2003. It calls for the construction of 3,000 luxury condominiums and a hotel along Ocean Avenue on the shore; the conversion of a vacant 1897 department store, the Steinbach Building, on Cookman Avenue into 60 condominiums and new retail space; and the construction of affordable housing.
City Manager Terence J. Reidy says Asbury Park's government is becoming more effective. In the past year, it has improved tax collection from a paltry 70 percent to the high 80's. "Ninety-five percent is considered good," Mr. Reidy admitted. "And as we collect more taxes, our ability to borrow to finance infrastructure improvements will go up."
This year, Asbury Park's most famous asset, its beachfront, has started coming back. According to Mr. Reidy, on the July 4 weekend, the city sold $20,000 worth of beach badges, at $4 each, compared with total badge sales of $74,000 last year. "Clearly we have a long way to go, but we are making progress because people don't come to the beach unless something is happening in the city."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
Builders Turning to Condos From Luxury Rentals

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
WITH mortgage rates low and the median price of a single-family house in Westchester out of the reach of many (it was $525,000 at the end of the first quarter of 2003), apartment developers are abandoning plans for new luxury rentals in favor of condominiums.
 Often more affordable than houses, condos appeal to families just starting out as well as to empty nesters leaving larger homes behind. Even young professionals who traditionally rent because they often change locations are being lured by low interest rates to buy into the county's thriving condo market, confident they can sell for a profit when the time comes to move on. 
 The shift in emphasis to condos can be clearly seen on one city block here in the downtown area, where Louis R. Cappelli, a Valhalla-based developer, is finishing a 35-story rental tower with 300 studios, one- two- and three-bedroom apartments going for $1,700 to $4,000 a month and laying the foundation next to it for a high-rise condo project. Across the street, an "apartments available" sign is posted outside an existing Tudor-style, midrise rental building. 
Instead of a planned second tower with 300 rental apartments, Mr. Cappelli is building 35 floors for about 220 two- and three-bedroom ownership units, said Marge Schneider, an executive vice president for Cappelli Enterprises. A 29-unit loft condo project by the company is under way next to the two towers. The tower condominiums are expected to range in price from $600,000 for a 1,300-square-foot apartment to as much as $2 million for a 3,000-square-foot unit. The lofts will be priced at $450,000 to $1.2 million.
"Market studies showed us that this was the right time for luxury ownership units in Westchester," Ms. Schneider said. 
The residential towers are part of a $320 million City Center on 7.5 acres in the heart of the downtown area that also includes 400,000 square feet for retail stores, 88,000 square feet for a 15-screen movie theater and 30,000 square feet for restaurants. The tower apartments are among 1,800 living units that White Plains has approved since 2000 to infuse new energy into its downtown.
But with interest rates as low as 5.875 percent for a 30-year conventional mortgage with 20 percent down on a condo costing less than $300,000, said Edward Weidberg, a mortgage adviser at American Home Mortgage White Plains, the rental market has not generated much interest. And with adjustable rate mortgages, the borrowing rate is even lower. In response, leasing agents are offering incentives like a month's free rent to lure consumers instead of lowering the asking rents, because they expect demand to increase as rates rise. 
"I wouldn't say there's a glut of rentals, but there's certainly a lot of product available," said Frank Cantatore, a partner in Clayton Park, a 260-unit apartment house that came on the market in November. Rents begin at $1,850 for a one-bedroom apartment and go up to $3,000 for two-bedroom corner units, with the first month's rent free. About 70 leases have been signed. 
Elsewhere in the city, 502 rental units have come on the market in recent months at Bank Street Commons -- a twin tower complex next to the Metro-North Railroad station. To date, 61 apartments have been rented. Units there range from $1,950 for a one-bedroom apartment to $3,075 for the highest-priced two-bedroom unit. Bank Street Commons is offering one month rent free to new tenants and a coupon for $1,200 that can be applied to rent, said Esther Mena, the leasing manager. The complex is also waiving the $300-a-year amenities fee for new tenants, she said. 
An additional 281 apartments are being built on the southern fringe of the downtown area by JPI of Irving, Tex. 
Like Mr. Cappelli, Mr. Cantatore had planned to develop a second rental project. But he has also decided to build condos instead and will start building 10 Windsor Terrace, a new $39 million, 10-story building with 71 units, within the next six months. The one- to three-bedroom condos, covering 1,200 to 2,200 square feet, will sell for $500,000 to $900,000, Mr. Cantatore said.
"It doesn't surprise me that some developers would change course or even retreat to the proven sector of condos," said P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors. "The rental market -- while I'm optimistic about it -- is much more speculative. We don't have a lot of history with new rentals, especially at the high end, which is what many of the new units are."
THE growth of the condo sector is being seen not only in White Plains but throughout the county, said Martin Ginsburg, an owner of the Ginsburg Development Corporation of Hawthorne. He attributed the softness in the rental market to low interest rates, as well as the softness of the economy. "A good part of what drives rentals is job creation, and that's not happening," he said.
In a project in Peekskill that was originally conceived of as rentals, Mr. Ginsburg is now building 201 condo town houses and triplex units at Riverbend on 21 acres overlooking the Hudson River. Prices will start in the low $200,000's and reach more than $500,000, he said. Occupancy is expected in 2004. In Pelham, Ginsburg Development is planning to build 67 condo units, costing $400,000 to $700,000.
In downtown New Rochelle, another condo project is under way: 72 work-live lofts in a former five-story Bloomingdale's store. After six weeks of marketing, more than 50 units in the $15 million Davenport Lofts project have been sold, said Mona Gora-Friedman, one of three principals, along with Stuart Polinsky and Joseph Klaynberg. Prices at Davenport Lofts start at $275,000 for one-bedroom lofts of 900 square feet and go up to $500,000 for penthouse lofts with terraces, she said. The first units are expected to be occupied in late October or early November.
Older condos are also selling well, said Patti Cunningham, a co-owner of Cunningham & Schneider Realty in White Plains. Even with the price increases in condos in the last year, they remain an affordable alternative for many buyers, she said.
The median price of a condo in this year's first quarter was $275,500, up 15 percent from a year earlier, according to the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service. Sales of condos increased by 9.8 percent, to 246,from 224 in the year-ago quarter.
And while the median sales price of a single-family home in Westchester rose 12 percent in the first quarter of 2003 from the year-ago period, the number sold dropped 13.7 percent, to 942, from 1,092.
Ms. Cunningham attributes the shift to condos in part to the high price of homes. One customer, a retired teacher who did not want to continue renting with interest rates so low, decided to buy a single-family home. But when he found little available in his price range -- the low $200,000's -- the teacher chose an older one-bedroom town house condo, a corner unit with a patio, in Ossining for $217,000. Another couple with a small child, looking for a three-bedroom house, instead chose a three-bedroom, two-bath condo for $289,000.
"Both cases are typical of what we're experiencing with customers who want to own but can't afford a single-family dwelling," Ms. Cunningham said.
While individuals may be moving away from the rental market, however, others see opportunity. James R. Tully, a vice president for CB Richard Ellis, said his company had recently negotiated the sale of Lexington Place Apartments in downtown White Plains to Korman Communities of Plymouth Meeting, Pa. According to Joseph Cerrato, an agent with Prudential Rand Realty in White Plains, the sale price was $19 million. Mr. Tully said some apartments in the 16-story, 124-unit rental complex would be furnished and leased to corporations. Studio apartments rent for $1,350 a month, and two-bedroom units for $2,050. The apartments, which average about 720 square feet each, are too small for conversion to condos or co-ops, Mr. Tully said.
"What we're seeing is that there's still room in the market for rentals," Mr. Tully said. "Not everyone is able or ready to buy, and some people don't have the down payment. Besides, interest rates will eventually creep back up, and the market will shift again. It always does."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/Fifth Avenue and 38th Street; 
An 11-Story Brick and Limestone Palace of Retail

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
LORD & TAYLOR is one of Manhattan's most venerable stores, established in 1825 and established at 38th Street and Fifth Avenue in 1914. An ongoing installation of new windows on the 11-story brick and limestone palazzo provides a good opportunity to consider whether architecture is made up of solids -- or voids.
 Samuel Lord and George Taylor opened their first store on the Lower East Side, but they were long out of the picture by 1912, when Lord & Taylor bought the northwest corner of 38th Street and Fifth Avenue, a commanding site and almost a full block front. 
 In 1913, the store filed plans for one of the most elegant large storesever built in New York, more suave than Macy's and more inventive than Saks. Over a limestone base, the architects Starrett & Van Vleck put an Italian Renaissance-style facade of gray faced brick, topped by a giant colonnade of marble and a copper cornice. Delicate "L&T" relief panels flank the entrance, and Roman-type screens with delicate cresting marked the show windows. 
In 1914, when the store was completed, the magazine Architecture said that the architects had been "fortunate in having clients who advocated a generous and progressive policy" with the result that "the public has received a gift and a benefit."
This spirit extended beyond the building's lot lines, for Lord & Taylor included a series of ramps for its electric delivery wagons to go to the basement; The New York Times said in 1913 that the store was grateful to the city that gave it prosperity and "will not embarrass it by lining the street with delivery wagons and packing cases."
The main floor was decorated as carefully as the smaller shops popping up on Fifth Avenue, with a ceiling of low arches, rich buff travertine columns and the floor in travertine bordered with black Numidian marble veined with gold. On the fourth floor, the store had an Adam-style salon with a great stage and spotlights "for trying out theatrical effects of handsome costumes," The Times said, and, on the seventh floor, a concert hall with a pipe organ.
Apparently, the 10th floor had no merchandise whatsoever, only a great dining complex for 500: the oval Wedgewood Room, with Adam-style decoration and a glass dome, a Chinese-style Mandarin Room, and the Loggia, in the red and gold of an Italian villa, and great French windows that could be opened up to make the room like a balcony in the summer. The 11th floor was largely devoted to the employees, with an open-air promenade, a solarium, a gym and a medical facility.
The main-floor show windows were not dressed in place but were built in pairs set on tracks: a new window was prepared in the basement, and switched with the old in a matter of minutes. Even the main doorway on Fifth Avenue had a platform in the basement, raised to form a display when the store was closed.
Architecture magazine singled out something normally left aside in most architectural discussions: the windows. A 1914 article noted that, in place of the typical upper-floor windows on commercial buildings, designed economically with large sheets of glass, the new Lord & Taylor windows were divided into small lights, as they would be on a much smaller building or even a town house. "A daring spirit," an anonymous writer said in the magazine. "Thus we have escaped the slavery of plate glass."
A 1915 article in the same journal by the architect Jerauld Dahler expanded on this theme, maintaining that high-rise buildings of steel-frame construction were really solids and voids -- the masonry and the nearly black glass of the windows, which created a hollow, sunken appearance. 
But on the Lord & Taylor Building the multipaned windows above the second floor -- up to 20 panes for some of the larger ones -- created a series of "delicate lines which we feel, rather than see, transversing the open area of the window openings, being of the same color and value as the walls themselves" and uniting the face of the building.
Dahler even reproduced comparative photographs, one of the building as it was, with buff-colored multilight window frames, and with the frames painted out -- demonstrating the "black eye" effect he described.
The ground-floor store windows figured in a disputewith the Fifth Avenue Association in 1938. In a November of unseasonably warm temperatures, Dorothy Shaver, an executive who was later president of Lord & Taylor from 1945 to 1959, conceived the idea of staging a continuous blizzard in the windows (created with cornflakes) with no merchandise, only signs admonishing "It's coming! Sooner or later!" According to The Times, winter clothing sales increased 50 percent even though the temperature was in the 70's. 
But almost immediately the Fifth Avenue Association protested to Walter Hoving, president of Lord & Taylor, that the store had violated a ban on motion in Fifth Avenue windows intended to keep out cheap trinket shops. Lord & Taylor took the windows down with some grumbling, but the ban was soon lifted and visiting Lord & Taylor's delightful Christmas windows is still a standard ritual for many New Yorkers.
NOW many of the same stores that moved up to Murray Hill with Lord & Taylor -- Vantine, Bonwit Teller, McCreery, Altman, Franklin Simon -- are names unknown to most New Yorkers, tossed into the dustbin of New York's retail history. When the giant B. Altman closed on 34th and Fifth in 1989, it left Lord & Taylor on a cliff of retail geography, like a large beachfront house where erosion now approaches the front porch.
A trip through the store now reveals little of the 1914 building. The original light fixtures are in place, but the walnut and ebony display cases are gone, and only patches of the Numidian marble floor have survived successive remodelings. 
The original travertine ceilings, arches and columns have survived, but the columns are covered with strips of mirror, and the ceilings and arches are obscured by many coats of paint. The elaborate 10th-floor dining rooms, the employees' solarium, the spotlighted stage, the concert hall and the ground-floor dual show-window are but a memory, if that. Balconies have been removed from the exterior, and the rich ground-floor limestone is hidden by paint.
This summer scaffolding went up around Lord & Taylor for a massive window replacement project. Dana Marnane, a spokesman for Lord & Taylor, says the new windows are being installed on top of the old ones to save energy, although she declined to provide any figures on the projected savings.
"It will appear slightly different, a more fresh look with the new clean windows," she said. From a few surreptitious inspections -- like one in a men's changing room on the north side of the 10th floor -- the original windows appear to be sound, although the paint is peeling from the exterior. 
The original window color was light, midway between the buff limestone and the soft gray brick. But the new windows are the familiar dark brown color that has become the default for such installations, and fake window muntins. 
But in this case the muntins are either carelessly made or poorly installed, at least in the work completed so far on 38th Street. There, they bow out from the glass surface, revealing them as artificial add-ons and reinforcing (rather than diminishing) the black-eye effect. 
As for the flat brown color, Ms. Marnane would not say why Lord & Taylor had chosen it. It would be out of place with the original light masonry of the 1914 building, but the facade is now so soiled and dark that the brown actually forms an appropriate complement to what was, in 1914, a noble work.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME; 
The Appeal Of V.A. Mortgages

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
MORTGAGES guaranteed by the Department of Veterans Affairs have traditionally been regarded by residential specialists with less than high enthusiasm, but these loans offer characteristics -- notably a zero-down-payment option and an ability to be passed on to a subsequent buyer of a home -- that make them a financing option worth considering. 
 Such mortgages -- commonly referred to as V.A. loans -- are attractive because they allow veterans to purchase a home with no money down and without having to pay private mortgage insurance that is usually required when the down payment is less than 20 percent. The loans are also appealing because, unlike most conventional mortgages, they are assumable by a subsequent buyer on the same terms and conditions that the veteran received. 
 While such loans have been available since the end of World War II, they have traditionally been viewed by real estate brokers and lawyers for both buyers and sellers as being more trouble than they are worth because of the time and red tape involved in applying for them. 
Over the past several years, however, the Department of Veterans Affairs has been streamlining its application procedures -- and tweaking its regulations -- to make obtaining a V.A. loan nearly as easy as applying for a conventional mortgage. And with interest rates now at historic lows, mortgage experts say, the fact that V.A. mortgages can usually be assumed by a subsequent buyer could give those who obtain such loans now a distinct advantage when the time comes to sell.
"There are a lot of misconceptions out there about V.A. loans," said Monique A. Beaudoin, loan production officer for the V.A. regional loan center in Manchester, N.H. Among those misconceptions, Ms. Beaudoin said, are that V.A. loans cost more, take much longer to process and require much more paperwork than conventional loans. 
"I was a lender back in the 80's" she said. "And getting a V.A. mortgage was a lot more complex back then."
Ms. Beaudoin explained that under the V.A. loan program, an estimated 29 million veterans are eligible to obtain mortgages of up to $240,000 to buy (or build) homes without making any down payment whatsoever. (Some lenders will make loans of up to $300,000, with a $15,000 down payment.) Frequently, she said, V.A. loans are somewhat easier to qualify for because a more generous formula is used to determine a buyer's ability to pay.
In addition, Ms. Beaudoin said, lenders who participate in the V.A. "automatic processing" program typically do not have to wait for the government to approve a mortgage application. In fact, she said, veterans who already have V.A. mortgages and want to refinance can do so in as little as a week.
The first step in obtaining a V.A. mortgage, Ms. Beaudoin said, is for the veteran to obtain a certificate of eligibility. Generally, she said, veterans who served on active duty during wartime for 90 days or more are eligible. Veterans with service only during peacetime must have had more than 180 days of active service, and veterans of enlisted service that began after Sept. 7, 1980, or officers with service beginning after Oct. 16, 1981, must, in most cases, have served at least two years.
Also eligible are current full-time active-duty military personnel who have served for at least 60 days; reservists and National Guard members who were activated on or after Aug. 2, 1990, and served in the Persian Gulf War for at least 90 days; and Guard members and reservists who served in support of operations in Kosovo, Afghanistan or Iraq for at least 90 days.
In addition, reservists and National Guard members who have completed six years of service and have been honorably discharged or who are still serving may be eligible. Those who believe they may be eligible for a V.A. mortgage, Ms. Beaudoin said, should complete a "request for a certificate of eligibility" (found on the V.A. Internet site,
homeloans.va.gov/lgyinfo.htm) and submit the completed form along with copies of the most recent discharge or separation papers or a current statement of service.
After a certificate of eligibility has been received, she said, the veteran shops for a home. Once a home is found, the veteran contacts a mortgage lender. If the lender is authorized by the V.A. to do automatic processing, Ms. Beaudoin said, the loan can be closed without V.A. review of the credit application. (Approved lenders are listed on the agency's Web site.) Loans from other lenders require V.A. credit approval.
After the loan is applied for, Ms. Beaudoin said, the lender must order an appraisal from an appraiser designated by the V.A. "This is the only thing that we do differently," she said, explaining that while most lenders hire their own appraisers, the V.A. insists that the appraiser be chosen by the agency. 
That, however, is one reason that lawyers, brokers and, frequently, sellers, are hardly overjoyed when a buyer indicates he or she is applying for a V.A. loan. "The V.A. appraiser comes in and goes through the house with a fine-toothed comb," said Peter Bell, an agent for Balch Buyers Realty in Mamaroneck. "It's almost like they're doing an inspection instead of an appraisal."
Another thing that makes sellers uncomfortable with such deals, he said, is the fact that in most cases, the buyer has no money on the line. "The seller says, 'I don't really want to deal with a V.A. loan,' " Mr. Bell said. "They say they would rather deal with somebody who has 10 percent or 20 percent down than somebody who has no down payment." 
But veterans who are able to buy a house using V.A. financing could find they obtain a significant additional benefit. Ms. Beaudoin, the loan production officer, explained that V.A. loans are assumable by a subsequent buyer subject to the V.A.'s approval. This means that when the veteran decides to sell the home, the buyer may be able to buy it without having to obtain a mortgage on his or her own.
"Assumability is a great feature when it's time to sell," Ms. Beaudoin said. While the person assuming a mortgage issued on March 1, 1988, or later must be approved by the V.A., obtaining such approval is said to be no more difficult than it would be for the buyer to obtain a new mortgage.
For example, imagine that a veteran buys a $200,000 house with a $200,000 mortgage and two years later wants to sell the house for $240,000. With an ordinary mortgage, a buyer would have to make some sort of cash down payment -- typically, 20 percent -- and would have to pay all the costs associated with obtaining the mortgage.
With a veteran's mortgage, on the other hand, if the buyer has a $40,000 down payment -- an amount that is actually less than 20 percent -- he can buy the house by paying the $40,000 cash to the seller (plus whatever amount the seller has paid against principal) and assuming the seller's remaining obligation on the mortgage. Buyers can save even more money when buying a home and assuming a veteran's mortgage after interest rates have risen.
A veteran who obtained a 30-year V.A. mortgage earlier this year, for example, might be paying 5.5 percent interest. If, two years from now, rates have risen, say, two percentage points, to 7.5 percent, a buyer assuming the V.A. mortgage would get the benefit of lower monthly payments, and the original owner would be released from the mortgage. While one does not have to be a veteran to assume a veteran's mortgage, she said, if the buyer happens to be a qualified veteran, the seller's entitlement for a V.A. loan is "freed up" and he or she can get a zero-down-payment V.A. loan on the next house as well. 
Ms. Beaudoin pointed out, however, that the V.A. usually charges the veteran 2 percent of the loan amount for a zero-down-payment mortgage -- commonly referred to as the "funding fee" -- and this is usually in addition to the 1 percent origination fee charged by most lenders. On the other hand, there is no requirement for the buyer to pay any monthly mortgage insurance premium. "And the funding fee can be included in the loan," she said.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Retirement Savings, In a Higher Gear?

BYLINE:  By Jennifer Bayot

 BODY:
People saving for retirement may find even more tax benefits as early as next year.
 A bill now making its way through the House, with bipartisan support, would speed up changes laid out in the 2001 tax relief law. 
Among other provisions, that law provided for a gradual increase, over five years, in how much workers may contribute to their 401(k) and individual retirement accounts. The current legislation would put the highest limits into effect in 2004, instead of 2006. 
 Employees would be able to set aside a maximum of $15,000 in their 401(k)'s, up from $12,000 this year and $10,500 before the 2001 law.
Workers with I.R.A.'s could contribute up to $5,000, an increase over the maximum of $3,000 in 2003 and $2,000 in 2001.
People over age 50 could make additional, catch-up contributions of $5,000 to their 401(k)'s, versus an additional $2,000 in 2003. Or they could put $1,000 more into their I.R.A.'s, compared to $500 this year. 
"Everything here is really a boost toward getting people to save more towards retirement," said Steven G. Lockwood, president of Lockwood Pension Services in New York and co-author of the annual "Individual Retirement Account Answer Book" (Aspen Publishers). "It's a way to get more money back into plans faster, to replenish the market losses that have occurred over the last three to four years."
Older workers may see an additional benefit: the legislation would push back the age that people must begin taking out their retirement money, to 75 from 70 1/2. Jennifer Bayot

HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
The Career Break That's No Holiday

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS

 BODY:
MICHAEL WARREN still shudders when he thinks of his first day as a car salesman in Greensboro, N.C., last July. "It was 100 degrees outside and I was standing on a black asphalt lot sweating in a long-sleeve white shirt," remembers Mr. Warren, 54, who had been fired the year before from his $175,000-a-year job as chief operating officer of a technology company.
 But the heat wasn't the problem. Nor were the payments on commission, which amounted to less than minimum wage. It was the way his new boss treated him, he said. 
 "I've closed deals in countries all over the world, and here is this worm instructing me on the basics of selling as if I didn't know anything," said Mr. Warren, who lives in Greensboro. "It was one of the most humiliating days of my life."
Mr. Warren isn't alone in feeling bitter about having to take a job he considers well beneath his qualifications and experience. In this rocky economy, the median duration of unemployment last month was the longest in 20 years, according to the Labor Department, and more and more high-level workers are having to take low-paying stopgap jobs while continuing to seek work in their chosen fields.
"Conventional wisdom has always been to spend all of your time on the job hunt, looking for the position you really want," said Phil Simshauser, vice president of the Center for Executive Options, a subsidiary of DBM, the human-resources consulting firm. But Mr. Simshauser said that the typical displaced executive was out of work for 7 to 10 months, and that waiting for the ideal job was "a luxury that many people can't afford."
Damian Birkel, founder of Professionals in Transition, a nonprofit support group for out-of-work executives that is based in Winston-Salem, N.C., has seen an increase in the number of unemployed upper-level workers taking lower-status jobs. In the last few months, Mr. Birkel said, he has worked with a former corporate financial officer who got a job stirring paint at Home Depot, and several former executives who signed up to work for the North Carolina government supervising the cleanup after ice storms last winter.
These jobs can halt the financial bleeding, he said, but can often be "a big blow to your self-esteem."
That was the experience of Mr. Warren, who lasted about four months at the car dealership, all the while looking for a position as a senior executive of a small technology company. When he couldn't stand it anymore, he took a job as a mail courier at a local law firm.
But that job was no better. Mr. Warren spent most of last winter hurrying around downtown Greensboro to deliver documents, often in sleet or rain. At the firm, "I was told to be invisible," said Mr. Warren, who left in April. "It was like I was some kind of house servant."
Some career experts recommend that unemployed executives try to find a stopgap position within their fields. Lance Hurley, corporate director of client services for Bernard Haldane, a career management company based in New York, has advised several unemployed corporate finance managers to take accounting positions with a temporary-employment firm like Accountemps. "When smaller companies in particular hire temporaries, some of them are really auditioning candidates for a higher-level job," he said.
Neil Lebovits, president and chief operating officer of Ajilon Finance, a staffing and recruiting company in Saddle Brook, N.J., estimates that about 20 percent to 25 percent of those who take temporary positions through the company end up getting offers for permanent jobs.
But an executive who takes a temporary job is unlikely to have the responsibilities of a permanent employee. Mr. Lebovits said he had recently placed a man who had been a chief financial officer into a temporary job with the same title. The man was dismayed to find himself excluded from board meetings and strategic planning. "That infuriated him," he said. "He was used to being able to help make big decisions."
Mr. Birkel of Professionals in Transition says executives who take lower-status jobs often have to reduce the amount of time they spend searching for a more suitable position in their field.
But not all stopgap jobs are without promise. Some executives have been able to make business contacts. 
Dr. Debra Condren, a business psychologist in New York, recently worked with an executive who had been laid off from a global communications company. After his unemployment benefits ran out, he took over a dog-walking service for a traveling neighbor and began chatting up the dogs' owners.
ONE owner gave him a lead that resulted in a job in his field. It pays $17,000 less than he made before, and the responsibilities are fewer, but he views the job "as a way to keep himself more in demand while searching for a position" that is better, Dr. Condren said.
One way for executives to keep their self-confidence during a stopgap job is to find a company that values their expertise, said Jane Caryl, president of Recruiting Intelligence Ltd., a business in Manhattan. 
Ms. Caryl recently helped place Peter Paradiso, a longtime Citibank executive, into a temporary position as an administrative worker at a Manhattan financial services firm. Mr. Paradiso, 55, took a retirement buyout from Citibank in October 2001 and has been trying to find work as a college professor.
Last April, Mr. Paradiso took the temporary assignment for financial reasons and was pleasantly surprised to find that the company preferred temporary workers with unusual talents and extensive experience. He rubs elbows daily with musicians, writers and some former executives in his age group. "I knew this was going to be an adjustment," he said. "But the people around me really appreciate my background, and that makes all the difference." 
Mr. Warren said that for now, he was hoping to avoid taking another stopgap job. He has created a spreadsheet to help figure out how much money he needs to survive, and to help pay tuition for his two children in college. "I've got 10 months before I go bust," he said. "If I don't find something in that time, it's back to punching a clock somewhere, in some job that I'm going to hate."

HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE LIFE: THE BOSS; 
Language of Experience

BYLINE:  By DAVID HELENIAK; Written with Glenn Rifkin.

 BODY:
I GREW up in St. Paul, where I was good enough at football to be recruited by the University of Michigan. I played my freshman year and then decided that I was better off focusing on my studies. I did, however, become a lifelong Michigan football fan. 
 One of the real turning points in my life came at the London School of Economics, where I earned my master's degree in economics in 1969. The school was, and is, a truly international institution, and it has long been known for its tradition of liberal thinking. I remember that just before I went there, my father took me to lunch with a colleague of his. This fellow turned to me and said: "Don't turn into a Commie. You know, J.F.K. went there." 
 I didn't turn into a Commie, but I did participate in some of the student unrest during that period. Remember, it was 1967 when I arrived there, so things were pretty intense. 
I had classmates from Nigeria, Mexico, Luxembourg, Turkey, Canada, the U.K. and many other places. Going to school and living in London with my wife, whom I'd met in history class at Michigan, I got turned on to current affairs, read The Times of London every day and listened to the BBC.
I later joined Shearman & Sterling in the London office, and when I was asked to run the Hong Kong office, my background served me well. I had the opportunity to meet with Jiang Zemin, who went on to become China's president. I also became one of the first Western lawyers to represent the People's Republic of China in major commercial dealings with the West.
I don't speak a word of Chinese but I consider among my very good friends some people who speak no English. If we were in a room together, we couldn't speak a word to one another, but we would know what the other thought, having gone through a lot together.
I served as a legal counsel for the Treasury Department in the Carter administration, and one time I was negotiating with three gentlemen from the Swiss central bank over terms for selling United States government bonds in their country.
During the three or four days ofnegotiations, they would speak to one another in Swiss German whenever they wanted to discuss something privately. One day, one of them sneezed and, with my Minnesota upbringing, I said, "Gesundheit," one of the only words in German I know. From the looks on their faces, they obviously thought I had understood everything they'd said. 
As much as I love the law, I am equally enamored of the arts. I did some legal work for the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, N.H., the country's oldest artists' retreat, and as a result I was asked to join its board. They found me to be a conciliatory force between the artists and lay people on the board and soon asked me to become president. It has been incredible. On this beautiful 440 acres are studios where writers, composers and visual artists come to work and create. I've gotten to meet Leonard Bernstein, John Updike, Martin Scorsese and William Styron.
My interest in the arts led to one other signature moment. I got an opportunity to be on "Saturday Night Live." I just had a walk-on moment in one skit. But the musical guests that night were Paul Simon and Willie Nelson, so, you can imagine, it was great to be there.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS; 
Long After Graduation, Business School Alumni Return for Job Help

BYLINE:  By KAREN ALEXANDER

 BODY:
MEGAN FRANK wasn't what most business schools would consider a particularly loyal alumna. She received her M.B.A. from the Goizueta Business School at Emory University in 2001, took a job in brand management at the Atlanta office of Eastman Kodak and didn't look back.
 Then, in April, Ms. Frank was laid off from her job. Her severance package was thin, the economy was weak, and she knew she had to look anywhere she could for leads. Through her alma mater, she found a pleasant surprise: a job. 
 Like other business schools that have scrambled to help their displaced alumni navigate shaky economic times, with varying degrees of success, Emory's employs a full-time career coach focused exclusively on the needs of graduates. 
Good M.B.A. programs have always made it a priority to help current students land their first jobs after graduation. After all, job placement rates and strong career services are the currency by which graduate business schools build their reputations. But many programs -- including state and private schools -- have decided that providing lifelong career guidance to their graduates pays handsome dividends as well.
Happy, loyal, gainfully employed alumni are more likely to help replenish a school's coffers down the road, and can be priceless conduits back to their companies for other alumni and current students.
Ms. Frank, 29, took advantage of her school's free online resources and one-on-one career counseling. And by networking at a school-sponsored happy hour in Atlanta, she landed a position as a consultant for the Zyman Marketing Group just a month after she was laid off. She describes the position as her dream job and says she is even earning more money.
Working through her business school network gave Ms. Frank an instant sense of community, and she now says she intends to repay the favor many times forward. "It's almost an unspoken obligation," she said. "Now that I've been in the situation, when someone calls on me for help, I'll do anything I can to help someone else out."
Business schools' career placement programs have long had open-door policies for their alumni. But the paltry job market of the last couple of years, and a deluge of requests from out-of-work alumni, have prompted many schools to redouble their efforts. (The unemployment rate rose to a nine-year high of 6.4 percent in June, leading even more people to ride out the job drought in graduate school.)
The schools say the alumni programs have become increasingly popular. It's difficult, though, to gauge these programs' success, because many schools have not kept track of the people using them.
Among the services for alumni are online resources, networking events and job-search seminars offered around the country, and one-on-one career coaching. As word has spread about the offerings, they have also become popular among people who already have jobs but are contemplating their next career move.
Helping alumni "has become a major issue of concern that schools need to respond to," said Sheila Steiner, director of M.B.A. career services at the David Eccles School of Business at the University of Utah. "A lot of schools are saying, 'I just finished putting away their resumes after they graduated, and now they're back.' They have seen a crush of alumni." Ms. Steiner is also on the board of the M.B.A. Career Services Council, an association of career services directors.
At Stanford's Graduate School of Business, a full-time position was created last spring to deal exclusively with the employment needs of alumni. In May, the Stern School of Business at New York University opened its Career Center for Working Professionals, with a staff of five, to work with alumni as well as the school's part-time and executive M.B.A. students.
"The typical recruiting that goes on at an M.B.A. program is by companies looking for entry-level M.B.A. positions," said Gary Fraser, assistant dean of career development at Stern. Now the school hopes to make inroads among recruiters who specialize in more experienced people as well, he said.
The Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern employs five part-time consultants (three near Chicago, one in Los Angeles and one in Atlanta) to work free with its alumni. At the Graziadio School of Business and Management at Pepperdine University in Malibu, Calif., the number of alumni seeking career development support has risen 25 percent in the last year. M.B.A. graduates now make up 40 percent of the people served by the business school's career resources office.
The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania now provides alumni with free access to otherwise costly online resources, like the business news service Factiva and the executive-level job search site ExecuNet. (ExecuNet, for instance, charges members $399 for 360 days of service.)
"We all got a little bit lazy during the boom years; we didn't have to get too aggressive," said Peter Degnan, who became the director of M.B.A. career management at Wharton 10 months ago after 20 years in investment banking. "Now the office has to be far more proactive for our students. And in reforming the department, we very quickly realized that the alumni world is a very important part of that."
WITH 77,000 alumni, Wharton can offer its students a powerful array of connections and networking opportunities. But at the same time, "we realized that a lot of alumni were having their own employment problems," Mr. Degnan said. "You've got to be able to give as well as take," he added.
Wharton has maintained an alumni job board for years but previously did not do much to promote it. Now, Mr. Degnan said, he is reaching out more to corporate recruiters, letting them know that "this is a really cheap, easy way for employers to tap into our talent."
So far, the number of job postings at Wharton is up nearly 70 percent since the beginning of 2002. In one recent listing, a major company was looking for a chief financial officer.
The University of Virginia's Darden Graduate School of Business Administration has maintained a career services office exclusively for alumni for five years, financed entirely through a private foundation established by the alumni. At first, about 80 percent of its patrons were employed. Now, about 80 percent of the people who use its services are out of work. 
"There's been a huge shift in the nature of what people need," said Herbert Crowder, Darden's director of alumni career services. A former banking executive who says his previous career often put him in the position of cutting people's jobs, Mr. Crowder has become a revered networking matchmaker among Darden alumni. His three-person office counsels about 750 alumni a year. "We pick up people who are in transition at a fairly tricky emotional time," Mr. Crowder said. He coaches the newly unemployed on everything from how to negotiate a severance agreement to understanding the job landscape. 
"Defining what comes next is as hard as finding it," he said. "Recent graduates should expect to take a minimum of six months to find the next job. More senior people can easily take 12 to 18 months to find their next job. They need to know that because they have to pace themselves emotionally, physically and financially. They need to get set up for the marathon that they're going to have to go through to reach the market."
With guidance from Mr. Crowder, Walter Shill, 46, of Washington, left his consulting job at McKinsey & Company to become chief executive of a start-up, Returnbuy, which was sold in March. Now Mr. Shill is consulting for another Darden alumnus whom he met through Mr. Crowder's web of alumni connections.
Mr. Shill, who received his M.B.A. from Darden in 1987, says that when he was a business student, he never considered what the school might offer him after graduation. But now he likens the experience to buying a car -- it has to work for you long after you drive it off the dealership lot.
"These days, if you're buying a car, you're buying a 100,000-mile or 5- or 10-year warranty," Mr. Shill said. "You're not going to learn everything you need to know in the first few years out of business school. I think of the career services the way I think of continuing education. It's like going in for a tuneup."
