HEADLINE: Has Billburg Lost Its Cool? 

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE

 BODY:
HE listens to Electroclash music, has 40-plus pals on Friendster and creates art with discarded household paint under the moniker Scooter. So when James Edward LaForge made the big move to New York from San Francisco two years ago, there seemed to be only one choice. 
 "Williamsburg," said Mr. LaForge, a goateed 35-year-old whose arms are plastered with tattoos. "I wanted to check out the art scene and live in a large loft." Through a lamppost flier, he found just that, a 2,000-square-foot apartment onNorth 11th and Berry Streets, in a grimy warehouse that had been carved into bohemian nests. 
 Outside his door, Mr. LaForge explored the cafe society of Bedford Avenue he had heard so much about. By day, he shared war stories with other hardscrabble artists over chai and iBooks. By night, he frequented the local bars, and groaned about Manhattanites who were crossing the East River and crowding his watering holes. "We called them bridge-and-tunnel," he said, appropriating the term Manhattan residents have long used to dismiss outsiders. 
 Then the edginess started to dull. "It's a cool spot," Mr. LaForge said. "But you know what? It started getting a little old. It started to get too cool and too hip. All the hipsters were dressing the same way. Sideways trucker caps, tight T-shirts, vintage jeans and Converse high-tops for guys. And for girls: very 80's studded belts, off-the-shoulder shirts, leg warmers and asymmetrical haircuts." 
 A few weeks ago, Mr. LaForge turned his back on Williamsburg, swam against the current and landed on Avenue C, in the heart of the East Village. "As an artist, I feel more inspired here," he said. Another thought dawned on him as he unpacked that first night. "I felt like I had finally arrived in the city."
 A smattering of recent statistics, combined with an increasing amount of anecdotal evidence, suggest that Mr. LaForge is among a growing number of hipsters who are making the reverse migration from Williamsburg, back to the granddaddy of counterculture and underground chic: downtown Manhattan. 
 Although statistics pointing to migratory patterns are notoriously difficult to ascertain, a recent report by Citi Habitats, a Manhattan brokerage firm, shows that 80 percent of the new leases in Manhattan last year were signed by people who already lived in or near the city, compared with only 50 percent three years ago. The shift suggests that more New Yorkers are shuffling from neighborhood to neighborhood to take advantage of lower rents. 
 And anecdotal evidence suggests that some of this movement is back across the East River.
 "At first, we were losing them to Brooklyn," said Adam Diamond, the owner of Hart Diamond Real Estate, a Manhattan firm that bills itself as "Manhattan's leading downtown broker." "But now they are starting to come back."

The Hipster Shuffle
 Plenty of hipsters are still ardent Williamsburgers and would never live anywhere else. And many of them are skeptical about any hipster exodus from Brooklyn to Manhattan. From where they lounge, their neighborhood is as up-to-the-nanosecond as ever, if not more.
 "I don't know who made up this story," said Fabio Roberti, a partner of Earwax Records, an alternative music shop that has been on Bedford Avenue for 12 years. "Obviously, it's to the benefit of Manhattan real estate brokers, isn't it? They stand to make more money if they can turn the tide around."
 And Williamsburg is hardly over. Since the mid-90's, a growing number of fledgling galleries and fashionable boutiques have taken root where working-class ethnic communities once intersected. They offered something fresh and charmingly proletariat at the time when Manhattan seemed to fall under the spell of dot-com millionaires. The indie music scene pulsated with new sounds. Experimental galleries served up fresh names that defied easy categories. New party spaces were carved out of musty warehouses.
 But after the nth visit, at least for some, the ebony reflecting pool at Galapagos lost its novel sheen. Eateries such as the Diner, which paired upscale food withgreasy-spoon nostalgia, no longer seemed original, especially after its format was copied, not once but twice.
 To some extent, the self-proclaimed hipster capital of New York, if not the world, was a victim of its own P.R. As the neighborhood's cachet started to rise, so did rents. In 1996, the median rent for a one-bedroom apartment in Williamsburg was $800, compared with $1,600 in the East Village. For half the rent, an East Village defector could have twice as much space.
 But the gap soon started to close. During the recent economic boom, Williamsburg was outstripping most of the city in rent increases. Ads for $3,000 lofts were not uncommon. After the bubble burst, rents in Williamsburg largely held steady, while they slipped in the rest of the city.
A one-bedroom apartment now hovers around $1,600 a month, according to Kenn Firpo Realty in Williamsburg. Meanwhile, the average rent for a one-bedroom apartment in the East Village has continued declining and is now about $2,000 a month, according to Citi Habitats survey. Throw in a roommate or two to share the rent and utilities, and the difference begins to zero out. If the Williamsburg scene grew out of real estate pressures, as so often happens in this city, the reverse may be happening now.
 "It's a no-brainer," said Lionel Beehner, a 27-year-old freelance writer and musician who last month traded a three-bedroom apartment near South Second Street in Williamsburg for two bedrooms and a loft on East Seventh Street in the East Village. His share of the rent, divided among two other roommates, is now $850, compared with $725 previously, and he feels that the slightly higher price tag is more than worth it.
 "You lose a few square feet in space, but you gain a better neighborhood, a great night-life scene and a real neighborhood feel," Mr. Beehner said. "My own room is bigger. We have a dishwasher and a back yard. It's a great place to be in your 20's."
 By comparison, Williamsburg struck him as more like a third-world country.
 "My room was a closet that faced a deserted lot, the floors creaked and nothing worked," he said. "There were only a few grocery stores, and the area looked like a bombed-out war zone. It was easier to find a 70's checkered-plaid T-shirt than it was to buy a TV dinner."
 Phone calls have started pouring into some brokerage firms. "One out of every three calls I get these days is from Brooklyn," said John Chubet, a sales agent for Croman Real Estate, which specializes in downtown rentals. "A lot of artists who are starting to make money are looking to move back into town."
 Although apartments in the East Village are typically smaller than those across the river, brokers are quick to point out amenities that Williamsburg lacks, like the four Korean delis down the block or an actual bank, as opposed to a mini-A.T.M. inside a bodega.
 "People consider it a lifestyle upgrade to relocate to Manhattan," said Andrew Heiberger, president of Citi Habitats. "I think 95 percent of people who can afford it prefer to live in Manhattan. A lot of young people, and they are pretty much the ones who make up the rental market, are now realizing the inconvenience of being a pioneer. I call them the displaced Manhattanites from the dot-com era."

Is It Hot or Not?
 To gung-ho Williamsburgers, those faithful readers of Time Out New York who concur that their borough is, as the magazine put it last year, "the epicenter of all things hip," the reverse migration is almost treasonous. After all, they had renounced their Manhattan citizenship, pledged allegiance to the artists' colony across the river and were issued new passports in the form of unlimited-ride MetroCards.
 "The so-called hipsterati are very proud to be here," said Jason Jeffries, the founder of a community Web site called Billburg.com and a Williamsburg resident since 1996. "I wouldn't say they look down at people who live in Manhattan. But this is the hot neighborhood. It's got a very fresh energy because of all the young, creative types in their 20's. The beauty of the neighborhood comes from the inside out."
 "I don't even own a MetroCard," Mr. Jeffries added with a self-congratulatory air. "I have no need to go into Manhattan." 
 Predictably, when bar crawlers from Manhattan began showing up on Bedford Avenue, armed with Citysearch printouts like clueless tourists in Times Square, Williamsburgers reacted like any self-respecting New Yorker: they turned up their noses.
 "They are coming here, and clogging our restaurants and bars," said Alice Amory, a real estate agent who lives in Williamsburg. "It's annoying. It's a yuppier crowd. The neighborhood right now is at a very discovered point."
 But with the real estate tide now trickling in the opposite direction, some Manhattanites are wondering whether the hipper-than-thou posturing was just posturing. Only yesterday, they say, Williamsburg pioneers were calling their neighborhood "Avenue E."
 "Absolutely, it was envy," said Mr. Heiberger of Citi Habitats. "Nobody wants to admit they are priced out of something. This is not a slant on people who can't afford $1,400 studios. I think the Manhattan market is absurd. But when Williamsburg was hyped up as the hottest new neighborhood, the qualifier should have added: if you can't live in Manhattan." 
 Some stirrings are coming from within. If lower rents in Manhattan were not reason enough to move, some Williamsburgers are finding the tribal mentality in their neighborhood suffocating and any resemblance to bohemia lacking.
 "The Hipster Handbook" (Anchor Books, 2002) written by a Williamsburg author, list 10 species of the urban creature, ranging from the UTF (Unemployed Trust-Funder) to the WASH (Waitstaff and Service Hipster). So why, many residents wonder, does everyone in Williamsburg dress alike?
 "Everyone is trying so hard to be different," said Jess Holl, 23, an editor at Black Book, a glossy culture magazine, "but in the end, they end up looking the same. It's not the same artsy community I first saw back in 1999. When too many people hop on the Williamsburg bandwagon, it's time to get off."
 Williamsburg residents say that they are reexamining their neighborhood, and are finding themselves trapped inside a cliche. "If I see one more small dog tied in front of a coffee house" said Ms. Holl, not bothering to finish the thought.
 "I'm tired of Williamsburg," added Ms. Holl, who lives in a converted warehouse on Kent Avenue with three roommates. The East Village has so much more variety." 
 Fashionistas, in particular, say they are starving for more eye candy. "Everybody looks like they stepped out of Urban Outfitters, times a thousand," said Haesther Libbey, a fashion model. "Everybody is either an artist, a model, a photographer or some rich kid who doesn't do anything."
 Ms. Libbey is moving next month from a converted warehouse on Kent Avenue to a one-bedroom in Midtown. Her first choice was the East Village, but, desperate to get out, she "took the first thing that came." 
 Williamsburg watchers predict that the bashing is likely to get louder. In a city addicted to finding the next hot spot, few things are more damning than overexposure. The beginning of the end may have come in 1997, when Utne Reader magazine anointed Williamsburg the third-hippest in America, just behind the Lower Garden District in New Orleans and the Inner Mission in San Francisco.
 "Outside of New York, Williamsburg is still spoken of constantly as the hipsters' place, which will probably make New Yorkers disdain it more," said Ann Powers, author of "Weird Like Us: My Bohemian America" (Simon & Schuster, 2000).
 Some are even declaring the Williamsburg scene officially over.
"Williamsburg is definitely no longer underground," said Larry Tee, who started the Berliniamsburg club in Williamsburg, which is credited with popularizing Electroclash, one of the neighborhood's best-known cultural exports. But last Saturday was the final night for Berliniamsburg. "Six months ago, Williamsburg was terminally hip," Mr. Tee said. "Now it's become designated as a safe space for nice people who have boring 9 to 5 jobs."

In Search of Bohemia
 It wasn't always so. With its gritty industrial architecture and raw cement floors, Williamsburg once offered the sort of dump that only an artist could love. Save for a couple of bodegas, the streetscape was an ugly wall of roll-down gates and the stray dandelion poking through the pavement. 
 Using their bare hands, the artists installed their own plumbing, electrical and sewer lines, and transformed vacant factory floors into a maze of ramshackle bedrooms and airy art studios. But the year was circa 1979, and the artists who were the original homesteaders are light years away from the ones making Williamsburg their home today.
 "They are cranking them out of the art schools and dropping them on the L train platform," said Eve Sussman, a video artist who first arrived in Williamsburg in 1992 and counts herself among the second wave of arrivals. "The people who live in Williamsburg now are like the 10th wave."
 The pattern is familiar to anyone who has groused about SoHo's becoming a shopping destination, or about French bistros replacing the far less savory haunts of Avenue C.
 "If you look at the cycles of bohemia in New York, you have pioneers who move into a neighborhood before there is even an A.T.M.," Ms. Powers said. Artists form a beachhead that eventually catches attention, and becomes a magnet for galleries, boutiques, restaurants and bars. Then trendy outsiders start pouring in and, before long, the pioneers are priced out of their own neighborhood.
 By that measure, Williamsburg is well into the final phase, one in which deep-pocketed developers start pouring money into undeveloped property as if they were spaces on a Monopoly board. A dozen projects are currently under way on and near Bedford Avenue, the main drag. Empty lots and warehouses are being transformed into full-service residences, with names like the Williamsburg Mews, Williamsburg Gardens, Bedford Court and the Photo Gallery Building. 
 Any debate about gentrification is couched in the past tense. "Williamsburg is the hip spot to live and develop," declared Helene Lucknick, an executive vice president at Douglas Elliman and the sales agent for Bedford Court at 292 Bedford Avenue, where condominiums range from $300,000 for a one-bedroom unit to $730,000 for a duplex penthouse. "Half of the 31 units sold within seven days of showing. I've never seen this before. They were all first-time homeowners. All young professionals and artistic types. Not artists, but artistic types -- graphic designers and literary agents. It's the hottest area in New York." 
 A minor milestone was reached this month when a brownstone near the Bedford Avenue subway station broke seven figures and sold for $1.3 million, "a record sale in Williamsburg in terms of a single family home," said Ingrid Johnson, a senior associate broker at the Corcoran Group. Construction is likely to accelerate. Last month, the city unveiled a proposal to rezone large swaths of the manufacturing district to allow for residential towers.
 Robert Lanham, the author of "The Hipster Handbook," and the founder of a Webzine called Free Williamsburg, would seem like the last person to knock the neighborhood. But when Mr. Lanham, who has lived in Williamsburg since 1996, looks outside his window, he sees what he called the "paradox of hipster culture" slowly coming to an end.
 "Williamsburg is having an identity crisis," Mr. Lanham said. "It's kind of absurd that these kids who went to fancy schools are dressing like they're construction workers. The struggling artist is a myth. Williamsburg is a pseudo bohemia."
 Rather than stick around, Mr. Lanham has started an apartment hunt himself.
 "I even looked at a couple of places in Manhattan," he said. "If I can find a nicer place with cheaper rent, I'll take it. I'll go wherever the best rents take me."

HEADLINE: Page Two: July 20-26; 
THE READING FILE

 BODY:
Is Bush Pulling the Wool Over Media Sheep Eyes?
 IN the August issue of Harper's, Lewis H. Lapham describes what he calls the American news media's willingness "to believe the government's reasons for sending the tanks eastward into Eden" in the eight months prior to the invasion of Iraq. 
 "The Bush administration's buncombe artists could tell any story they pleased about Western civilization being held for ransom by Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction," he writes.
Citing "The Politics of War" by Walter Karp, first published in 1979, Mr. Lapham compares the current scene to the era of the Spanish-American War and World War I. 
The sinking of the Maine in 1898 and of the Lusitania in 1915 provided "the promoters of American empire with the same sort of causus belli as was presented to the Bush administration by the destruction of the World Trade towers in September 2001," Mr. Lapham writes.
He notes that "Spain's fifth-rate colonial power in Cuba was depicted by the McKinley administration as 'the most wicked despotism there is today on this earth."' He compares Theodore Roosevelt's attacks on "ultra-pacifists," "poltroons" and "mollycoddles" to Rush Limbaugh's attacks on Susan Sontag and Harvard.
He sees similarities in "the distribution of alarmist propaganda -- Germany in the summer of 1915 said to be capable of landing, in a matter of 16 days, 387,000 troops on the coast of New Jersey."

No Longer a Relic: A Revolver Renaissance
THE revolver is maligned unfairly. It has many virtues.
So says Chuck Taylor in the August-September issue of Guns and Ammo Handguns.
The last rites to the revolver were all but said in the 1980's due to the popularity of the 9-millimeter. But over the years, revolvers have reappeared in stores and sales have inched upward. "It is still as accurate, rugged, reliable, "user friendly' and powerful as ever," he writes.
He says the revolver does not jam and can hunt any kind of game, unlike the 9-millimeter, which has limited range and power to hunt anything but small critters. 
"If, like me, you've ever faced an annoyed mountain lion on a rock ledge eight feet away, with a 9-mm. auto, you'll know what I mean," he says. "It's better -- much better -- to have a .357, .41 or .44 Magnum or a heavy loaded .44 Special, .45 Colt or .45 Auto Rim."
He admits to the revolver's one shortcoming. "It a bit tougher to shoot under stress" but this does not invalidate it as a self-defense weapon, he says.
Guns with large magazines falsely suggest that the more ammunition, the higher the odds of hitting the target. Reality suggests otherwise.
"Year after year, the F.B.I. Uniform Crime Report shows statistics indicating that there are less than five or six shots fired per encounter, which are well within the wheelgun's capacity," says Mr. Taylor. 
Later in the article he states, "Multiple misses don't count -- it's hits that get the job done."

Questions Are Raised About 1991 Civil Rights Act
DID the Civil Rights Act of 1991 improve employment opportunities for women and minorities? 
The legislation -- which significantly expanded the rights of plaintiffs in discrimination complaints on the federal level -- was basically ineffective, according to an article in the summer issue of Regulation, published by the Cato Institute, a libertarian research group.
The act fueled invalid fears about quotas and did not improve hiring "in fields with traditionally low representation of women and minorities," the authors of the article say.
The study was conducted by Paul Oyer, an Associate professor of economics at Stanford University, and Scott Schaefer, Richard M. Paget associate professor of management policy in the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University.
They write that the act mainly increased the cost of dismissing workers protected by the legislation.
As a result, employers reduced their hiring of protected workers, shifted their means of dismissing protected workers toward layoffs and away from individual firings and placed a premium on protected workers who are least likely to sue.
"Firing-based protections lead employers to hire fewer protected workers, not more," the authors say.

HEADLINE: The Country America Cannot See 

BYLINE:  By Mun Yol Yi; Mun Yol Yi is author of "Our Twisted Hero," a novel. This article was translated by Bruce Fulton, Ju-Chan Fulton and Brother Anthony from the Korean.

DATELINE: ICHON, South Korea 

 BODY:
Today is the 50th anniversary of the cease-fire that ended the Korean War. The division of the peninsula by two "liberation" armies -- both of which seemed to hold it in no special favor -- was an unwelcome gift thrust upon the Korean people, still dazed by the emotions of liberation from Japan in 1945. The intense nuclear anxieties on the Korean Peninsula now demonstrate the lingering effects of this gift. 
 The regimes imposed by the Soviet Union and the United States on North and South Korea at the end of the Second World War evolved quite differently -- and not necessarily in the way Americans assume they did. 
 One side, thanks to a shrewd, quick-witted guardian, got what it was promised (the North). But the other side, owing to the obtuseness and confusion of its imperial benefactor, failed to develop into the strong democracy it was expected to become.
The Soviets, who had been thwarted by nationalistic sentiments while trying to export the socialist revolution to Eastern Europe in the 1920's, immediately handed North Korea over to the group led by Kim Il Sung and withdrew, leaving no military administration behind. As a result, Kim seized power without serious damage being done to his nationalistic credentials. What's more, the rapid creation of a system of one-party rule formed a good basis for the idolization of Kim Il Sung. For just as the Japanese had replaced Korea's Yi dynasty with their emperor in 1910, Kim Il Sung took the throne left empty by the Japanese emperor, who had been banished by the Soviet troops. 
In comparison with what happened in the North, South Korea's search for its proper role was chaotic and drawn out. The American forces arrived as liberators -- yet the military government they established in 1945 resembled the heavy-handed one the United States imposed on the Philippines after the Spanish-American War in 1898. 
Without regard for the nationalistic feelings among Koreans, the military administration put people who had collaborated with the Japanese in official positions. Only after three years of questionable military rule did the United States approve the establishment of an independent government in South Korea.
Those three years -- from 1945 to 1948 -- did lasting damage (in the name of democracy), bringing about at least two changes in the consciousness of South Koreans. 
First, the idea of a monarchy was completely demolished. While the other East Asian kingdoms saw a restoration of their monarchies after the Second World War, in South Korea the topic was never properly debated. Had a new monarchy been created -- or had it even been discussed fully -- South Koreans would have had an outlet for their nationalistic sentiments.
Second, there was among South Koreans an unrealistic level of belief in and hope for freedom of expression and thought. (Except, of course, when it came to discussing a monarchy.) As opposed to the North, the government in the South was obliged to permit every kind of political party in the name of democratic pluralism. 
These two factors set the stage for the Korean War. In South Korea, the lack of a strong leader and the excessive openness of society enabled the country's Communists to grow stronger and stronger. The chaos they created, the acts of terrorism they committed, made civil war inevitable. 
And here we are, half a century later. What has changed? What has stayed the same? North Korea still maintains its hereditary system of rule without any dissent. It continues along its appointed path. South Korea, on the other hand, is struggling to find itself. I have the feeling, if I may exaggerate only slightly, that we are returning to the anxieties we felt before the Korean War.
These anxieties are particularly evident in the vicious battles between left and right in South Korea over reunification and political and economic reform. With greater and greater frequency, demagogues on both sides identify their opponents as evil. 
These anxieties are apparent, too, in the widespread and intense anti-American feeling among Koreans. Anti-Americanism has always been around, but until recently it has usually been embraced by a minority only. When we see the lack of outrage among South Korean students at the fatal shooting of five of their number by the North Korean Navy -- a contrast to the repeated calls for justice for the two girls killed by American soldiers driving a tank -- we must assume there are changes in thinking among these students that go beyond simple nationalistic feelings.
We may never understand why America committed troops to the Korean Peninsula in September 1945. And we may never know, truly, why those troops have stayed here since. But I think we can say with some certainty that America never expected to find itself in its present situation in South Korea, and in particular to be treated as an enemy.
The problem of American policy toward Korea has been endlessly debated and analyzed. Still, if there is anything to add it is this: the American perspective on Korea has changed little since the end of the 19th century. As John King Fairbank, the historian, made clear in "East Asia: Tradition and Transformation," in the Pacific War America fought Japan for China; in the Korean War, it fought China for Japan.
When I first read these words roughly 20 years ago I failed to catch their full significance, but over time this sentence revealed to me the American perspective on Korea. Namely, even though America's young people fought and shed blood on Korean soil, Korea was not a part of the American consciousness. For America, Korea has always been understood as a part of China or a part of Japan.
It was the same when it came to the armistice. There were more than 3.5 million victims of the Korean War. One in 10 Koreans was killed or wounded; one in three was forced to experience the agony of living separated from family, in North or South. Yet when the armistice was signed, although China was there with its North Korean ally (having replaced the Russians), there was no place for Korea. The South Korean representative was the American general acting as commander in chief of the United Nations forces; no South Korean representative was present.
It seems that still now, 50 years later, nothing much has changed. At the recent Beijing talks on the North Korean nuclear crisis, Korea, especially South Korea, was absent. China met North Korea, and America, to discuss nuclear disarmament on the Korean peninsula, but I wonder if even there America, while recognizing the existence of North Korea, did not consider it to be part of China.
There is no more effective way for foreigners to provoke Koreans than to view Korea as part of China or part of Japan. Naturally, from this standpoint it's difficult for Americans to expect a positive response from Korea. Although it is late in the game, America must make space for Korea, and especially South Korea, in its consciousness. In East Asia there is in addition to China and Japan, Korea. A Korea distinct and separate.

HEADLINE: A Push to Make la Difference Verboten in the New Europe 

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ

DATELINE: LONDON, July 26 

 BODY:
Picture Italy without its curvy, half-clad television hostesses. Imagine a Western European city where men and women pay the same amount for insurance, regardless of how recklessly they drive or how long they live. Ponder going to school in Britain without Jack the engineer and Jill the nurse.
 That is what Anna Diamantopoulou, the European commissioner for employment and social affairs, envisioned in proposing far-reaching legislation to outlaw sexual discrimination in areas like television programming, advertising, insurance premiums, taxation, newspaper content and education. 
 The proposal is the boldest step by the European Commission to make a coherent social policy on everyday gender equality, an issue that is gaining momentum and causing heartburn for many large industries.
It would, in effect, push the prohibition on sexual discrimination beyond the confines of work, trade and labor, which is already regulated, into untouched realms. Why, for instance, it asks, should a woman pay more for life insurance? Or why do baby-changing stations exist in women's restrooms but not men's?
"Economic progress is no longer sufficient," said Mary McPhail, the secretary general of the European Women's Lobby. "We want much more social policy and a much wider commitment to all of Europe."
To be enacted, the legislation requires approval by the commission, which is the European Union's executive committee, as well as by the European Parliament and the union's member countries. But it may not survive criticism from lobbyists in Brussels, where the European Union has its headquarters.
The proposal is under intense scrutiny and may be watered down or abandoned, say lobbyists and union officials. It will be revisited by Ms. Diamantopoulou in September.
"It is unacceptable in its current form," said Angela Mills Wade, the executive director of the European Publishers Council, which represents 29 media companies. "If you took it to its logical conclusion, you would have to make sure your editorial content didn't describe or portray women or men in a way that could be interpreted as being discriminatory. That would severely curtail editorial freedom."
The lobbying blitz effectively slowed the bill's progress, illustrating that lobbying in the European Union, where the exercise is downright ponderous and academic, can be just as effective as in Washington, even without the American traditions of campaign donations, golf junkets to Hawaii and lavish dinners.
Dr. Catherine Hakim, a sociologist at the London School of Economics who studies women's issues, said the office of the European Commissioner for employment and social affairs had long had a "dogmatic, determined approach" to gender equality.
The commission successfully expanded laws against gender discrimination in the workplace, and it is now turning to its next challenge.
"They are constantly pushing the boat out," she said. "There is no question that they do have a role within the social field. What is more debatable and is more in dispute is, whether having exhausted the obvious avenues in sex discrimination and equal treatment, they are going well beyond the field."
Ms. Diamantopoulou's office emphasizes that she was granted a mandate to combat sexual discrimination -- along with discrimination based on age, race, disability and religion, among other things -- in 1997 under the union's Treaty of Amsterdam. The mandate dealt most obviously with the workplace, labor laws, trade, training and education.
"This is the second level of implementing the treaty combating gender discrimination outside the workplace," said Antonia Mochan, Ms. Diamantopoulou's spokeswoman.
Ms. Diamantopoulou herself declined to be interviewed. But in response to the furor her directive created, she wrote a column in The Financial Times on June 27 urging calm but defending her stance.
"I am determined to pursue it to its conclusion, in consultation with all concerned," she wrote. But lobbyists said they were appalled to find out about the directive only by reading about it in the newspaper. Most said that Ms. Diamantopoulou had overstepped her mandate.
"The problem with the proposal is that it's a blanket rule saying media should not contain any discrimination regarding sex," said Ross Biggam, the director general for the Association of Commercial Television in Europe.
Does it mean that British channels would not be able to broadcast shows about cars aimed at a male audience? If a channel runs a show on the sexiest men in Hollywood must they quickly follow with a show on the sexiest women? Or is sexy barred altogether?
The insurance industry was no less bewildered..
"It concerns so deeply the way we work," said William Vidoja, the deputy manager for the European Federation of the Insurance Industry, which represents 5,118 insurance companies.
He said insurance companies had long differentiated between men and women in calculating risk because they considered gender differences to be an "objective criteria." Women pay less for car insurance because they are safer drivers. Men pay less for life insurance because they die younger.
Changing traditional premium calculations based on gender would wreak havoc with the industry and ultimately drive customers away, he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 31, 2003

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about far-reaching legislation proposed in the European Union to outlaw sexual discrimination misspelled the name of a deputy manager for the European Federation of the Insurance Industry, who said that changing the gender component of risk calculation would wreak havoc with the industry. He is William Vidonja, not Vidoja.

HEADLINE: Steel Barriers Reinforce a Thinner Line of Blue at Parades, and the Bottom Line 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON

 BODY:
Nothing is more New York than a Fifth Avenue parade with screaming, flag-waving crowds held back by the familiar blue wooden sawhorse barriers and a police officer standing every few feet. Look again.
 The crowds are still there, but many of the barriers are now metal and linked and the officers are more spread out. By changing its security routine, the city saved $3.7 million in the parade season that started in mid-March and ended in mid-June. 
 The New York City Police Department, under pressure to cut costs and maintain levels of public safety, instituted the new method of crowd control at the traditional annual parades this year. By switching to the interlocking steel barriers, the department was able to reduce the number of officers assigned to the parade route, replacing them in part with more officers on blue and white scooters who can zip over in an emergency, city officials said.
The new approach was in effect for the 17 parades and 3 other big events during that three-month period, the most popular time of the year for the big street parties. The savings was achieved largely by cutting overtime more than 40 percent from what was spent on these events in 2002, city officials said.
The reduction in police officers is a function of the new barriers' design. Anyone can push a wooden sawhorse out of the way, or squeeze in between to get onto the parade route. With thousands of people crowding the curb, pressing up against the sawhorses, many did. 
But the new barriers are 43 inches tall, made of galvanized steel and latched together like a fence, so it is much harder to go over, through or around them.
In the last year, the city has bought more than 6,000 of the barriers, more than doubling its inventory. The design originated in France, said Chris Friedrichs, vice president of Friedrichs Custom Manufacturing of New Orleans, which sold some of the barriers to New York. He said the barriers first showed up in large numbers in the United States about 40 years ago at Mardi Gras in New Orleans.
There are still hundreds of officers stationed along the parade routes, and some wooden barriers are still in use. But by using more steel barriers and bringing in a larger contingent of officers on scooters, the department can have fewer officers on each block, unless there is a need to assemble more, according to the plan.
"We are using resources in a smarter way," Deputy Police Commissioner Paul J. Browne said. "We are not going to spare resources if we see any threat for any given event. But still, when you balance all the information at hand, you can use fewer officers and still have a safe event."
The city's budget crisis has driven down the size of the police force to 37,210, 3,500 fewer officers than the peak in October 2000. On top of that, 1,000 officers have been assigned to antiterrorism duties since the attack on Sept. 11, 2001.
Even with these cutbacks, citywide crime measured in seven major categories is down about 7 percent so far this year.
Parades, while a boon to the city's image, spirit and economy, have long been considered a costly strain on police resources. Deciding how much security to post at these events is an especially delicate task for the Salute to Israel Parade, because of concern about possible terrorism, and the National Puerto Rican Day Parade, because in 2000 mobs of men attacked and groped women in Central Park in the hours after the parade ended.
This year, police officials assigned a total of 11,411 officers to cover the 20 spring events, or an average of about 600 per event, although the number can vary widely depending on the size of the parade. Police officials said that even with fewer officers there was no appreciable increase in mischief or arrests. 
The directors of two of the biggest parades -- the Salute to Israel and the St. Patrick's Day parades -- said last week that they did not even notice the changes this year. Yet using more of the metal barriers saved the city at least $500,000 on each of these two events, city officials said.

HEADLINE: How to Vote? Let Us Count the Ways 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
There is a cynical precept of politics that says that those who cast the votes decide nothing, but those who count the votes decide everything.
 A third group, though, decides quite a bit, too: those who set the election rules. 
 New York City's election rules could be rewritten soon, if the voters approve Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to abolish party primaries in 2009. 
The mayor says his push for nonpartisan elections will lead to fairer elections. But fair can be in the eye of the beholder. While the pros and cons of the mayor's proposal will be debated in the coming months, it is worth noting that recent history is riddled with well-intentioned election reforms that ended up having unintended consequences. 
Think of the decision to hold the old community school board elections in the spring, so they would not be overshadowed in November. Voters forgot they were being held, or did not care, and turnout had to be measured with electron microscopes. 
Then there is New York's system of nominating candidates for State Supreme Court at judicial conventions, which was supposed to insulate the bench from politics. The thought now seems risible.
Or take a look at what happened with redistricting, which was supposed to preserve the one-person-one-vote standard by periodically redrawing district lines to take population shifts into account. In practice it regularly becomes an exercise in partisan gerrymandering, with the political parties redrawing electoral maps to guarantee themselves safe, uncontested seats. Redistricting, it has often been observed, turns the age-old principle of having the electorate choose its leaders on its head. 
Some scholars would go so far as to question whether any system of choosing a winner by way of a vote can truly be fair, at least when more than two candidates are concerned. 
Kenneth J. Arrow, a Stanford University economist, won the Nobel Prize in economics in 1972, in part for his work in the late 1940's and early 1950's for developing what came to be known as Arrow's Impossibility Theorem. It provided proof that there is no way to arrange an electoral system to perfectly reflect the will of the people when it comes to choosing a winner from more than two candidates.
"It was a little disquieting," Professor Arrow recalled last week, explaining that he had originally set out to find a good system.
What's the problem? Depending on how an election is structured, it is almost bound to have some imperfections from a mathematical point of view. 
In the American system, the candidate who wins the most votes wins the election, even if he (and it still usually is a he) falls short of a majority. That sounds fair. But does it accurately reflect the will of the people, to the extent it can be known?
Consider the last presidential election results from Florida. If you accept the final, much-disputed tally, it showed that George W. Bush got slightly more votes than Al Gore, and both men trounced Ralph Nader. So Mr. Bush won the state, and the presidency. But most people in Florida voted for someone other than Mr. Bush. And since most Nader voters would presumably have preferred Mr. Gore to Mr. Bush, it follows that Mr. Gore would have been a more acceptable choice to most Floridians than Mr. Bush. But second choices do not count in the American system.
A number of alternative election systems exist. A runoff election between the top vote-getters can be held if no candidate gets a majority of the vote. Such a system, though, can keep members of minority groups -- racial, ethnic or ideological -- from winning, even when they finish first in the initial count. 
In the Democratic mayoral primary in 2001, Fernando Ferrer, who forged a black-Latino coalition, beat Mark Green. But since neither man got more than 40 percent of the vote, a runoff election was held. Mr. Green won the runoff (only to lose the general election), and some of Mr. Ferrer's supporters complained that the runoff system was unfair.
Other countries use other voting systems. Many parliamentary systems use proportional representation -- an alternative to the American winner-take-all system -- in which parties are allocated seats based on their share of the popular vote. Such an arrangement gives a voice to smaller parties, giving their representatives a small number of seats. But critics argue that they create unstable governments held together by fragile coalitions.
Then there are systems in which voters rank their choices in some way. One such system of ranking candidates, and choosing the one at the end with the largest number of points, was championed by Jean-Charles de Borda, an 18th-century French scientist. And why was he interested in voting systems?
"He thought the wrong people were being elected to the French Academy of Sciences," said Donald G. Saari, a professor of economics and mathematics at the University of California at Irvine who has written several books about election theory. He said that the Borda system appears to be the fairest way of voting.
Many groups in the United States now advocate a ranking system called Instant Runoff Voting. Known by its avuncular-sounding acronym, IRV, this is a system in which voters rank their choices. If a candidate wins a majority of the vote on the first count, that candidate wins. Otherwise, the losing candidate is eliminated and those votes are accorded to those voters' second-choice candidate, and so on, until a winner gets a majority.
But changing voting systems can be even tougher than figuring out a butterfly ballot. For one thing, governing parties like to stick with the systems that brought them to power. For another, many new systems sound as if they came out of that New York State Math Regents exam, the one whose results were discounted because it was too difficult.
But it is not an academic question. Dan King, a professor of mathematics at Sarah Lawrence College, offered a hypothetical example to demonstrate how the choice of election system can actually determine the outcome of the election. 
Imagine nine people trying to figure out which actor was the best James Bond: Sean Connery, Roger Moore or Pierce Brosnan. (O.K., actually Professor King's example said that the nine people were trying to choose between candidates A, B and C, but this is not math class.) Four of them like Connery best, followed by Moore, followed by Brosnan. Three voters like Brosnan, followed by Moore, followed by Connery. And two voters like Moore the best, followed by Brosnan, followed by Connery. So who is the best Bond?
In a plurality system, Sean Connery would be the winner: he got four votes, while Pierce Brosnan got three and Roger Moore got two. But that's no majority.
But what if a runoff election were held? Roger Moore would be eliminated, because he got the least number of votes. But the Moore fans liked Brosnan second best. That would leave four voters preferring Connery to Brosnan, and five voters preferring Brosnan to Connery. Pierce Brosnan would be the winner of the 007 runoff.
And in a Borda count -- giving 1 point to the least favorite, 2 points to the second and 3 points to the favorite -- Roger Moore would be the Bond of choice.
"Three procedures, three different winners," Professor King noted.
In the coming weeks Mayor Bloomberg's Charter Revision Commission will come out with proposals for how a nonpartisan election system might work: how people will qualify to get on the ballot, whether runoffs will be held, what the thresholds will be. Some of those details could be as significant as their primary goal of abolishing primaries.
"You can skew the outcome of any election," said Burt Neuborne, the legal director of the Brennan Center for Social Justice at New York University School of Law, "depending on how you structure the democratic system."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Voters at the polls in Westchester County last November. Rules affecting how elections are run can have unintended consequences. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: To Save the City Money, Rikers Supersizes It 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON

 BODY:
The Bloomberg administration's vision of a leaner, more efficient New York City government can be found in an oven that bakes twice as many pieces of chicken in slightly more than half the time. The 6-foot-by-8-foot rotary-rack oven spins hour after hour in a kitchen that prepares meals for 6,900 inmates a day on Rikers Island, almost double the 3,500 it was built to serve just three years ago.
 Churning out that many meals means cooks like Cicely Williams have to work harder; she goes home with aching arms and swollen feet at the end of her 3 a.m.-to-noon shift. And to deliver the mass of food, pans must be stacked in an endless queue of insulated carts that are loaded into trucks that then rumble across the village of jails on the Rikers grounds. 
 But by creating super food factories, the city has been able to close five of the nine Department of Correction kitchens and save $1.5 million this year, eliminating 75 jobs. It is a drop in the bucket given the sprawling $43.7 billion enterprise that is New York City government and the $8 billion budget gap the city had faced this year. But it is one way in which that gap was closed. 
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg could not persuade city labor unions to agree to broad-based concessions to produce even bigger productivity savings. Having then raised property, income and sales taxes, the mayor and the City Council were under pressure to balance the budget without slashing services. 
That is where the city agencies and their commissioners came in. "Government can do things when motivated and pressed," said William T. Cunningham, the mayor's communications director, clearly implying that the agency directors were being squeezed. The Probation Department cut 41 jobs, saving $2 million, by allowing 25,000 lesser-risk convicts to check in at automated kiosks set up in the five boroughs, instead of with probation officers. 
The city expects to save another $10 million by buying in bulk food for feeding the homeless, people who eat meals at centers for the elderly, and schoolchildren. And the Bloomberg administration has vowed to serve just as many children in after-school day care services -- it currently accommodates about 170,000 -- but at a $14 million savings after it merges the management of a hodgepodge of programs into one agency later this year.
Even the city morgue has come through. Instead of two different agencies picking up and processing the dead, only one will, saving as much as $1.4 million this year.
Besides outright savings, the Bloomberg administration has pursued a second strategy to help dig out of the fiscal hole. You might call it passing the tab.
For example, the 105 centers for the aged in City Housing Authority projects, which offer everything from exercise classes to bingo, had cost the city $29 million a year. But since July 1, their operating costs have been transferred to a federally subsidized program.
Many agencies, though, did make significant cost-cutting changes. Among the most extensive were the operational rejiggering at the Department of Correction.
It was a logical place to start. Even before the enormousness of the fiscal crisis set in, the city jail system was flabby with resources because of the sharp drop in crime and a resulting decline in the inmate population, to 13,870 inmates one day last week from a daily average of 19,205 in 1997.
The first round of cuts were easy. The department simply eliminated extra capacity: five of the smaller or older jails, including the Houses of Detention in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens, have been closed since February 2000. But that was only the start.
The savings drive took Department of Correction officials into the kitchens. The department was already renovating them, but this spring officials decided to close three kitchens at the separate jails on Rikers Island and two elsewhere and to turn the remaining kitchens into virtually around-the-clock food factories. 
In years past, cooks would go into supply rooms and refrigerators, grab what they thought they needed for the day and start to prepare the day's meals from scratch. No more. Now every ingredient -- from cut green beans to ketchup -- is counted and stacked under signs that read "Monday's Dinner" or "Thursday's Lunch." 
Tight inventory control has allowed the city to cut the cost of the ingredients used in an average meal to $2.36 from $2.58 five years ago.
Early last Tuesday, in a kitchen that looks more like an airplane hangar, the staff and inmates were busy making four different meals at once: stirring 1,200 pounds of spaghetti and 210 gallons of sauce for Tuesday's lunch; arranging 21,800 hot dogs in pans for Thursday's lunch; cutting cucumbers for a salad for Friday's lunch; and seasoning 15,000 pieces of fish for Friday's dinner.
Although food prepared three days in advance does not sound particularly appetizing, inmates like Nelson Negron, 34, who is serving time for burglary and was cleaning in the kitchen, gave it a passing grade. "It's not so bad," Mr. Negron said. He paused, then added, "You got no choice."
The pre-preparation of most meals greatly reduced the time it takes to handle the food from start to finish.
"Food wagons walking out," yelled Andrew Jackson, a barrel-chested correction officer, referring to the 25 or so giant rolling, igloo-like food storage carts into which the hot foot had been placed so it could be driven by truck to a nearby jail. Until earlier this year, that jail had its own kitchen.
The gate locking everyone into the kitchen -- it is in a jail, after all -- was slid open and carts rolled. "Choo, choo," an inmate yelled, as the lunch train of sorts pulled out.
For kitchen employees, the intense focus on efficiency can be exhausting. "It is just more harassing now," Ms. Williams, the cook, said. A minute later, her boss asked, "We almost ready to start panning?" referring to the spaghetti she was mixing in a vat so big she needed a spoon the size of an oar. "A few minutes," she said. "That's my girl," her boss shot back, smiling.
The new supersized ovens are critical to the operation. Rikers Island's old kitchens used the equivalent of pizza ovens. The new contraptions -- so big they would thrill Hansel and Gretel -- can accommodate 500 pieces of chicken at once, 300 more than the old ovens, and, using forced hot air and rotating racks, cook them in 45 minutes instead of 90.
The kitchen is attached to the 2,461-inmate Anna M. Kross Center jail, Rikers' largest. Four officers and a captain used to be assigned to Kross's main control room, where they cast an eye on video monitors, manage guard assignments, keep track of a wall of keys and control the giant steel doors at the jail entrance. Today there are three officers and a captain doing the same work.
At the other end of the jail, where 150 or so inmates are lined up each morning on their way to court, two additional officers have been cut. That means Capt. Steven Cipriano, the supervisor, must focus on the machine that X-rays inmates' bags, instead of just standing in the corridor as he used to, keeping a more general watch on the inmates under his control.
"Would I rather have more staff here?" Captain Cipriano said. "Of course. If something should happen, we would have more coverage. But we are making it work."
Those small cuts have been repeated at dozens of posts across the city's jails. As a result, the Department of Correction's budget for this year calls for 8,771 city-financed full-time uniformed officers, a reduction of 1,122 in two years.
The next-most-ambitious restructuring effort under way this year involves several social service agencies. The city plans to save $75 million by changing the way it helps the unemployed get jobs, provides after-school care to young children and determines eligibility for benefit programs, like help for the elderly to pay their heating bills. 
Because the savings have been budgeted but not yet realized, some advocates for schoolchildren say they worry that the city will instead cut services -- for instance, put children from poor families that now get child care year-round into a program that operates only during school days. Bloomberg administration officials said that would not happen.
Others say the efficiencies may threaten the safety of workers left doing the job -- raising risks for firefighters, for example, by eliminating the fifth firefighter on 23 Fire Department engine companies, saving $11 million.
Some officials, though, argue that restructuring has actually improved service. At the Probation Department, those guilty of low-level offenses are required to check in according to a mandated schedule. But instead of seeing an officer, they can visit a kiosk that confirms their presence by electronically reading the shape of a probationer's hand.
That means the city's probation officers, relieved of having to meet regularly with the 25,000 or so people convicted of crimes like assault or fraud, can spend more time on the 9,600 serious criminals on probation.
At the same time, regular reporting by lesser-risk probationers is up, since many of them know that the computerized system allows the city to keep better track of them and to more quickly penalize those who do not report.
Will all these changes result in a municipal government that is truly lean and productive, or just slightly less wasteful? The Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group, argues that the city could save an additional $500 million a year by asking most civilian employees to work a 40-hour week, instead of the current 35 hours or 37.5 hours.
Another $200 million could be saved, the commission contends, by improving the way the city buys goods and services.
Still, the Bloomberg administration has clearly generated more than $100 million in savings by improving productivity. But unlike most other mayors, Mr. Bloomberg has been oddly reticent about publicizing the gains. 
Though the savings are far less than city residents are paying in new taxes, they have helped Mr. Bloomberg balance this year's budget without closing centers for the aged, cutting library hours, reducing trash collection, or taking other draconian measures that once had been threatened.
"Sometimes a fiscal crisis creates an urgency that allows you to do things that inertia has prevented," said Martin F. Horn, the Department of Correction commissioner. "The fiscal situation demanded these changes. But even if it had not, they were the right thing to do."

HEADLINE: HEALTH CARE; 
Failed Hospital Finds a Rebirth

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO

 BODY:
IT has been three months since St. Agnes Hospital, a small institution in White Plains founded almost a century ago to serve Westchester's poor, failed and went under management by the Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla. And while the present seems clear, and the bright, airy hospital has managed to start breaking even as a division of the larger medical center, it is by no means clear what the future holds for St. Agnes.
 The recent past, though, is painfully clear. The 184-bed hospital, founded by a Roman Catholic order, the Sisters of St. Francis, was squeezed by low payments from health maintenance organizations and government programs like Medicaid and Medicare, plagued by its inability to carve out a niche in the health care market in Westchester, and burdened by a $90 million debt. St. Agnes relinquished its operating license in early April. 
 Soon afterward, the state Dormitory Authority, one of its main creditors, moved to foreclose on the hospital. Hospital operations were then taken over by the Westchester Medical Center in an arrangement that is to last until mid-October. While many hospitals -- public and private, large and small -- across the nation are suffering from essentially the same problems of low reimbursement rates and high costs of medical care, few have gone out of business. Some use investment income to shore up operations; some dip into pools of reserves set aside for rainy days; some have turned to wealthy donors for bailouts; some aggressively court rich patients from abroad. 
But St. Agnes didn't have reserves, financial investments, wealthy donors or enough of a reputation to lure patients from overseas. To survive, it needed patients, and lots of them, who could bring in payments -- even if they are modest ones -- from H.M.O.'s and the government.
"Basically, they weren't getting the patients," said Claudia Hutton, the spokeswoman for the Dormitory Authority, which issued $38.5 million of bonds on behalf of the hospital for renovation in 1998. At the time of its demise, 125 of St. Agnes's 184 inpatient beds were occupied. 
No other hospital in the county is in danger of closing, said Craig Kornett, a health care analyst with Fitch Ratings, a Manhattan-based bond rating agency. "St. Agnes was in a unique situation," he said. "There is no other hospital in financial trouble at that level." 
He said that the New York metropolitan area is one of the most difficult places in the country to operate a hospital, because of its oversupply of health care services. The last time a Westchester hospital closed was in 1980, and that was the Yonkers Professional Hospital, according to the State Health Department. 
To Martin Arrick, a director at Standard & Poor's who specializes in the health care industry, the lack of a niche was St. Agnes's Achilles' heel. "There are a lot of hospitals in Westchester," Mr. Arrick said. "Everybody also has the option of going into New York City for medical needs. What you need is to find the niche that will make you needed." 
St. Agnes was a member of the Catholic Health Care System under the Archdiocese of New York. Brian Mulligan, a spokesman for the Health Care System, said in a telephone interview that the large number of medical centers in Westchester was a big factor in St. Agnes's financial woes. More than a dozen hospitals are in the county, and White Plains Hospital is about a mile away from the old St. Agnes. 
For now, Westchester Medical Center has turned the St. Agnes campus into the White Plains Pavilion of the center, making it its division that handles the overflow of patients from the Valhalla center, which has 1,060 inpatient beds. The center's chief executive, Edward Stolzenberg, said he is considering turning the St. Agnes campus into a permanent division of the center.
"But it's not a good idea to use it just as an auxiliary facility," Mr. Stolzenberg said. "Can we turn it into a heart hospital? Can we turn it into a cancer hospital? These are just some thoughts." 
While Mr. Stolzenberg said the medical center wouldn't decide about whether to acquire St. Agnes permanently until September, he was optimistic that an acquisition would take place. According to the Dormitory Authority, the medical center could either buy or lease the property from the agency.
If the medical center declines to either lease or buy the property, the Dormitory Authority would look for other hospitals to take it over, Ms. Hutton said. 
For now, with the business directed to the former St. Agnes's campus from the Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla, the division has started to break even, according to Mr. Stolzenberg, who was the president of St. Agnes for two years in the early 1990's. He has his own postmortem about St. Agnes. The hospital was overstaffed, he said, and failed to campaign aggressively to bring in patients.
If St. Agnes was filled to capacity, it might need its 600-member staff, he said, but when it was operating at about two-thirds full it needed far fewer staff members. In 1992, when Mr. Stolzenberg was at its helm, he established centers for cancer and multiple sclerosis at St. Agnes, which attracted some top-notch doctors in the field, he said. 
Mr. Stolzenberg took the job of running the Westchester Medical Center in 1993, and he said he felt that St. Agnes never widely publicized its new specialties.
Mr. Stolzenberg has his own work cut out for him. In March, he cut more than 100 staff members, and said the layoffs would reduce costs totaling $8 million a year. The hospital, managed under Westchester County government until 1997, lost $6 million in 2001 and more than $10 million in 2002. Mr. Stolzenberg has brought in some well-known surgeons who can perform expensive procedures, like heart and liver transplants, to compete with prestigious hospitals in New York City, like Mount Sinai and New York Presbyterian. 
For now, the mood among staff members at the former St. Agnes is "cautiously settled," said Dr. Robert Antonelle, gastrointestinal doctor there.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Warren Strugatch; E-mail: libiz@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Acclaim Entertainment Names New President
Acclaim Entertainment (Nasdaq: AKLM) of Glen Cove named Paul Eibeler, a former executive with Take-Two Interactive Software (Nasdaq: TTWO) of New York, as president and chief operating officer for its North American operations.
 Mr. Eibeler was president of Take-Two from January 2000 until April. Mr. Eibeler took a medical leave of absence and decided not to renew his contract, which expired this month, the company said. 
 Both Acclaim and Take-Two are among the video game publishers whose accounting practices are the subject of an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

TSR Reports Profits Drop
TSR (Nasdaq: TSRI) of Hauppauge, which provides computer programming consulting services, produced a profit of $537,000 for the fiscal year ended May 31, a decline of 13 percent over last year. Revenues fell 12 percent from the year before, to $52.4 million.
Last year, the company posted a profit of $690,000 on revenues of $59.5 million.
Joe Hughes, the company's chief executive, said continuing lack of demand in the current weak economic environment accounted for TSR's performance last year.

Arrow Electronics Board
Arrow Electronics Inc. (NYSE: ARW) of Melville named Stephen Patrick, the chief financial officer of the Colgate-Palmolive company, to its board of directors, the company announced on Tuesday. Mr. Patrick joined Colgate-Palmolive in 1982 from Price Waterhouse, and became chief financial officer in 1996.

NBTY Profits Decline
NBTY (Nasdaq: NBTY) of Bohemia, a manufacturer of nutrition supplements, reported on Tuesday that its third-quarter profit fell slightly to $29 million, from $30 million for the same quarter last year, while sales rose 22 percent.
NBTY said sales for the quarter increased to $308 million, from $252 million for the same quarter last year.
The company is currently completing a $250 million cash acquisition of Rexall Sundown, a vitamin manufacturer, from Royal Numico.
The company paid earnings of 43 cents a share, ahead of 36 cents a share anticipated by Thomson First Call. Compiled by Warren Strugatch

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Harmonic Convergence for Local Food and Wine

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
AS head of the Hampton Bays-based New York State Seafood Council for some 11 years, Roger Tollefsen already knows most of the people involved in commercial fishing on the East End. But at a planning session this month for Savor Long Island, a new campaign promoting local wines, seafood and agricultural products, he met a number of people -- mainly farmers, he said, but also winemakers and restaurateurs -- who had just become his partners in Savor Long Island, a campaign spearheaded by the Long Island Farm Bureau to raise awareness of the region's foods and wines.
 The idea is to spread the idea that local seafood, produce, poultry and wines taste better when consumed together, especially close to the source. A secondary goal is to encourage restaurants in Nassau and Suffolk to build menus around what Long Islanders catch, raise, harvest and bottle. 
 The campaign also seeks to position the experience of enjoying the East End's foods and wines as a motivation to travel east for the day.
Collectively, the sectors represented account for a significant portion of the regional economy. Suffolk County farmers produce about $185 million a year in sales, and the local wine industry represents about $65 million a year. Commercial fishing on Long Island produces some $50 million in sales, and duck farms, although much reduced from their heyday, still account for about $20 million.
Additionally, much of the money spent by tourists on Long Island goes to farm stands, restaurants and winery gift shops.
The campaign is clearly aimed at people in Nassau and western Suffolk counties. The farm bureau's Web site encourages visitors to become "tourists in your own back yard."
Mr. Tollefsen said that although fishermen were not included early in the campaign's planning, he quickly grasped the idea that they could accomplish more together than they could individually.
"We have a growing ecotourism that's tied to the farm stands," Mr. Tollefsen said. "It's been an economic rejuvenation for many farmers." Commercial fishermen, he said, could similarly benefit by creating greater market appreciation of their product.
"There's a tremendous opportunity to do more," he said, by linking the region's foods and wines in the minds of consumers and restaurateurs.
Savor Long Island was funded by a $100,000 state grant obtained by the Long Island Farm Bureau through State Senator Kenneth P. LaValle, whose district includes the East End. The print ads, which began running this month in several East End weekly newspapers and in Newsday, feature a fish shaped like Long Island on a plate, accompanied by a glass of red wine.
Additionally, a television campaign created by Black Sheep Productions, a studio in Bridgehampton, has been broadcast to local viewers of programs on the Metro, Food and Weather channels on Cablevision. The ads feature "images of farmland and people eating," said Krista Zilnicki, the public relations director of the farm bureau.
Joseph M. Gergela, executive director of the farmers' group, said that when the funding was received, he contacted the 700 members of the Long Island chapter of the New York State Restaurant Association and offered to help them showcase Long Island foods and wines. Part of the state grant went to printing new menus, he said.
At first, the ads named the participating restaurants. But that quickly became unwieldy, Ms. Zilnicki said. "We took the restaurants' names off the ad, and just directed people to our Web site," where they are all listed, she said. The site is www.lifb.com.
One evening at A Touch of Venice in Mattituck, one of the restaurants participating in the promotion, the Long Island menu featured a choice of goat cheese and strawberry salad, or local steamers, as an appetizer; and a choice of angel hair pasta with lobster meat or striped bass with sauteed chicory; and potato salad.
The meal is accompanied by a glass of Long Island wine, said Brian Pennacchia, whose family owns the restaurant.
"It's easy for us to be involved" in the promotion, he said. "We do it anyway. On my way to work I stop at the farmstand and get local lettuce, and I stop at the fish store for local lobsters. We already carry local wines."
Many of the vineyards on the North Fork, he said, refer their customers to his family's restaurant, in part out of appreciation for stocking their products.
"We carry their wines, they send us their customers," he said. "It all works hand in hand."
In a related promotion, local foods and wines will be paired next month in a new event called the Long Island Wine Classic. The event will be sponsored by Wine Spectator magazine and the Hamptons Classic Horse Show, one of the largest events of the East End and a highlight of the Hamptons social calendar; the show will open a day earlier to accommodate the event, which will offer samples of many Long Island wines and prepared foods.
Herodotus Damianos, who owns the Pindar and Duck Walk vineyards, envisioned the new campaign sparking tactics like those wine enthusiasts in California used years ago to help fledgling local winemakers gain a foothold.
"Wine buffs would walk into restaurants in California and order a local wine with their meal," Dr. Damianos said. "If the waiter said that the restaurant didn't carry local wines, they simply stood up and walked out."
Louisa Hargrave, a wine consultant in Mattituck who is helping the farm bureau administer the program, said the idea behind the campaign was logical.
"If you went to Bordeaux, France, you wouldn't order a Napa Valley wine," said Ms. Hargrave, who, 30 years ago, helped found the East End's first commercial vineyard. "Why in the world would you come to the East End and order a French wine, or a California wine?"
Ms. Hargrave said that despite its limited run, the campaign has already helped expand distribution of Long Island wines to restaurants west of Riverhead, long a goal of many of the winemakers.
"Some restaurants carry a local wine or two, don't promote them, and then drop them, saying there was no demand," she said. "Duh. Of course there was no demand. No one knew they were available."
Mr. Pennacchia, the Mattituck restaurateur, said that while the campaign prompted him to create a separate Long Island menu, doing so was simply good business.
"A lot of tourists come looking for that," he said, meaning the experience of buying local foods and wines. "We get a lot of people coming over from Connecticut by boat, and they always have a lot of questions" about what's on the menu and in the wine cellar, he said.
And Long Island customers?
"I don't know," he said, "that it means as much to local people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: James Campbell looking over a menu that emphasized Savor Long Island, an effort to raise awareness of the region's food and wine, at Touch of Venice in Mattituck. (Deirdre Brennan for The New York Times)
